Friendly!

Essential visit if you come to Toulouse, relaxing very carefully, a walk that does not get heavy since its trails make access even easy. Elderly people. Continuous paper.

Beautiful garden where it is good to walk and rest.
Super nice, quiet place. Green spaces, flowers, merry-go-round for children. We can picnic too. Very good.
Very pretty and very relaxing

Beautiful area. Quite a change of scenery.
Very well maintained. It's been traveling.
A great time to discover a little the Japanese world!
Very nice little park not to be missed in passing in the city 😀

Lots of people this Sunday, it's lovely even in winter!
A small air asia in the Toulouse .. quite nice.
Beautiful and very serene. The best is to go there when there are not too many tourists!

Very nice garden! Restful and always very clean ..
Always so beautiful. It's been 15 years that I no longer live in Toulouse and always a pleasure to find this garden
A very pleasant and friendly oriental touch in the Pink City.
Garden very nice and quiet .. playground behind for children. Perfect for everyone
Nice park in the center of the city. This Japanese park is integrated into another park. The visit is worth it
Greenery and calm Zen atmosphere
The truth is beautiful, worth a walk
Great garden, soothing, relaxing too well
Great places in Toulouse where you can walk around and breathe the fresh air!

Very beautiful pleasant garden certainly very beautiful summer
A small but charming place. To visit if you go to Toulouse.
Since my youth, I adore this magnificent garden. You can walk there. Land on a bench

Very pretty perfect for this found in a relaxing place
Really only "petit" but very well made and maintained on the few square meters. If there are not too many tourists running around, it is also relaxing there to just sit in peace and enjoy the time.

Very nice, the pity is that it is not bigger
Very beautiful shaded garden
Splendid and well maintained garden ... ideal Zen place!
trip: Go read a book or just enjoy the tranquility of the place. Beautiful, just beautiful. Pleasant walk and nice places to eat all around you after.

For me, the Jardin Japonais is standard on my walking tour when I receive friends on a visit. It is a nice relaxing place to have a walk, pauze for a while. You can even look at it with some educational added value and learn how a Japanese house was (or is?) constructed. The

It is obvious how much work has gone in to creating and caring for these gardens. It's just we expected a little more I guess. Tranquil vibe. Not well signposted and had to use google maps rather than local signs.

This was my 3rd visit to the Japanese garden and I'm really lucky to have seen it during different seasons (summer, autumn and winter) each time. The setting is idyllic, quiet and very relaxing. The garden is inside a much larger park which also includes a big children's play

Charming place with its paths to wander around. The red bridge crossing a small stream leading into the ornamental pond looks perfect in the photos. Worth a visit but please don't forget to visit the dragon in the public park surrounding these gardens - He's brilliant!
This is a lovely small Japanese garden located inside a public park. It’s really well maintained and a peaceful spot in the city centre to check out.

It is a beautiful garden. There is a section for children playground and a cafe there too. Another section is a pond with a fountain in the centre. See fishing activity there. There are many beautiful flowers in the park.
We walked through a public park and came across this little gem set in the middle. It's a really nice Japanese garden well worth a visit. And it's Free!!
A little bit difficult to find, it's a park in a park and not really signposted well. However, it it a very nice but small garden and worth a visit if in the area.
It is a very nice place to go on a sunny day and take a walk in the park, it is completely free too which makes it even better, considering how beautiful the park looks
A very beautiful garden that is enjoyable by both friends, family and even the younger kids in the family. We went on a sunday and it was a nice walk in the park with not too many people

What a gorgeous spot to sit and reflect or wander aimlessly within a picturesque and serene environment. I found a spot and sat to people watch and take in the lovely gardens. Some great places for pictures within also.
This is a favourite stop of ours And we adore the garden. Admire the planting, the fish, reflect on your day but don’t miss it!

A little piece of tranquility in a busy city center. I wasn't quite sure what to expect before arriving. When I arrived at the park that is connected to the garden I was even less sure of what to expect. I visited early in the morning and was surrounded by fellow
I went early in the morning and there were only 3 other people there. very pretty garden to walk around and well looked after.

They have done a nice job of making these Japanese gardens. It is completely fenced off, only one way in or out. There weren’t many people there, but some teen girls sitting in the shelter (pagoda?) were rather loud.
The gardens offer a clean and quiet space for relaxing. Close to metro but within 15 minute walk of Capitole.
Good place for a walking or jogging. More a relaxing place. Great for photos. Close by the Campaign-Cafarelly

Although not in the central part of the city this is worth the short metro ride to get to. It is well maintained in Japense style and is a lovely walk inside the main park. WE didn't spend as long there as some other reviewers but as its free you don't have to plan to spend
We saw some cherry blossoms to make up for not being able to be in Japan during Spring! The place is nicely kept but the pigeons kept stealing our food!

Walking bridges connect all the main Jardines here. Spent a few hours just strolling through them all. Took our lunch and grabbed a seat in the shade with other visitors and relaxed our way through rest of afternoon.
Small but still worth a visit. In the middle of a park in Toulouse but very Japanese. A visit won’t take too long but worth an hour or two.
To be quiet in Toulouse city center and have a peaceful moment, do not hesitate to go in one of the nicest Park of Toulouse. Maybe you'll have the opportunity to enjoy a little nap.
Worth a visit. Very nice and well maintained garden, quiet with lot of shade. There is a small pond in the middle with few turtles. I recommend to visit it
Beautiful Japanese gardens within a municipal park. Nice and relaxing and very pretty and picturesque. Lovely for a stroll in the heat.

Peaceful and relaxing place, it’ll worth your time! Go there just to have a look at this special creation near the center of the city. This Japanese Garden is surrounded by a big park. I’ve been there in a sunny Saturday afternoon and I really appreciated all these people lying
The park itself is not great, but the Japanese gardens are small, but perfectly formed. Well worth a detour.
Very well maintained gardens - very Zen. Lots of places to sit and relax, contemplate or just enjoy the scenery. Lovely plants and trees. A little haven in the middle of a city. Highly recommended.
A nice place to relax and recharge. In the centre of the Compans Caffarelli garden, you walk into a Japanese garden and tea Pavillion
Beautiful and park with play area for kids. Very refreshing - a must visit incase you are in Toulouse for more than 2 days.
We loved our hour or so wondering around the 3 large old gardens. So many huge trees and lots of colourful garden beds. It would be a wonderful place for a picnic lunch.
Well maintained Japanese garden, nice to visit on a spring day. The sand design is better than average, haven't seen one like it so far.

It's a nice place to visit. It's not huge, rather small I'd say. You may have already seen other Japanese gardens, if so, you won't probably be amazed about this one. Kids like it as it's not huge. And there's a place for kids to play close by.

A bit secluded but still walking distance from city center. Do not miss it by any reason as it is a pearl within the city. Plus there are panels that explain the culture behind the Japanese gardens if you are interested. It was so relaxing for us, the Japanese standards have
It was opposite of the Compans Cafarelli metro station. Inside of the Compans Cafarelli Jardins. It was a small but very peaceful place. You can spend one-hour taking photos and doing sunbath

My friend and I had a wonderful walk in this splendid spot, a Japanese garden within a public park. It was a delightful experience, a lovely walk on this Sunday afternoon. Worth the search... you will enjoy it! xxx
Small and nicely maintained Japanese gardens. Visited there couple of times with my family. There is also a children's play area and a eatery adjacent to the garden.

Nice Garden. Unfortunately not much going on flower-wise in February but also the size of the garden is smaller than anticipated. We went here on Sunday morning and it was packed with families with children so it is defo a cute place but I have seen nicer parks in other cities.
It's a clean and a relaxing place. Different as well. Worth the visit if you just have a couple of spare hours.
Nice smaller garden with lovely Japanese garden. Well done. Not sure it’s worth the trip from downtown but certainly if in neighborhood. Could do entire garden in 10-12 minutes or spend a lot longer.

Pretty parc but the actual Japonese garden is small and quite crowded on sunny days. If you are down in toulouse for a short amount of time then I would not include the garden in your must see list. If you're in the area then walk through the parc and enjoy a quick stroll. If

30 years ago this was a great idea and a great success! Sadly it is now frequented by all the drop-outs of society who treat it as home and I no longer enjoy visiting! It's high time the town hall get their act together and clean this attraction up VB before it's too late.
Beautiful place to visit during any season. Deserve a time in every tourist schedule. A place that provides great pictures. Easy access.
right outside our hotel so defo had to visit ..Its small but pretty and very well looked after ..ENJOY
Beautiful garden. It was raining and we hesitated to go. But, even we got all wet, we don’t regretted. You have to see it, is a little oasis of this city.

This is a small but stunning Japanese garden located in the centre off a park near Compans Caferreli metro. Very peaceful with small streams and pools with fish, bamboo, a zen garden and Japanese styled buildings. Free entry and worth a visit if you are in the area.

Worth the walk out from the city center to see the overall park plus the Japanese garden. Very nice landscaping and upkeep. Quiet and picturesque. Some millennials we're goofing off and security spoke to them right away.

Free entrance Absolutely amazing and very peaceful Calm and with lots of nature!! Very beautiful I recommend to visit during good weather / sunny day Beautiful bridge and dojo!!! Stunning views The Japanese garden is a garden inside the main one There are places to eat inside

Perhaps because we visited in February and most of the foliage was a distant memory, we didn't find it particularly attractive. It was nice to walk through to the garden and peaceful given the lack of tourists during winter. Would like to see it in full bloom.
These are very peaceful part of Toulouse that is definitely worth the trip out of the town centre. Lovely to spend an afternoon sitting and relaxing here.

This garden is part of the bigger park but is free to enter and walk around. Very well looked after the only problem is it is popular. If you want to take really good pictures an early start is advised
What a beautiful find this was on our walk around Toulouse. The garden is small but beautifully kept. The pond had huge goldfish and a wee turtle in it. A wee haven in the middle of the city
If you have time you must visit this garden. Good place to relax for few hours away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Is it because I already visited some Japanese gardens in other cities in Europe and in Japan, but I found this one small and not really interesting. You can walk around in 10 minutes and it's done ...
situated in a larger park, this is the place to have a moment of « time out » and quiet contemplation.

Well maintained gardens. Small but wonderful to see in a city that has very little parks. A 5 minute cycle ride from our apartment and we're in a good place. I even bring my studies to this park during the week.

This is tucked away in the far corner of a local park. It was worth seeking out as a tiny piece of Japan in the middle of a French city. We were enchanted. On the downside, as the weather was scorching we tried to have a relaxing sit on the grass in the shade of a tree, and

This park is so well kept it is a pleasure to visit. With well manicured trees, shrubs and grassy areas accompanied by a pond that is stocked with some impressive fish this really is a place to relax and reflect.

We visited here in the evening just before it closed. It is a lovely urban park and garden where families were enjoying themselves. There is a children's playground in one area and wonderful tree-lines paths all around.

A beautiful and quiet park to walk around. A nice change from the busy streets of the city. Beautiful sculptures, buildings and of course the bridge really help to make the gardens special. Plus the dragon sculpture just outside the gardens is impressive too!

The previous day all the city parks had been shut for reasons we didn’t find out so it was pleasant to visit these gardens next morning before our departure to get away from the general city hubbub and the smells of urine and dog excrement in the main streets. It won’t take you
This peaceful spot is great for a stroll in the garden. Lots of families enjoying each other... on a beautiful spring day with flowers blooming.
Slightly off the beaten track, but well worth a visit if you like this sort of thing. Set within a pleasant larger park, including a substantial children's play area wuth a huge rope climbing frame.
While in a very stresful end of year, we went their to chill and have somme quiet refreshinng time in nature...it was amaising.

We wandered about the gardens but the emphasis was on the playground, having 4 year old twins in tow. And it was a great place, well maintained. The area is clean, and there are lavatories available. Wide range of young childrens activities as well as some for the older kids.
These gardens are quite small however wonderfully maintained, tranquil and completely free. Worth a visit whilst escaping the touristic areas of Centre Ville.
This was a beautiful, quiet spot. A real Japanese garden. Not large, but worth finding in the larger garden.

Located a distance from the city center, close to the Canal du Midi, this is a park within a park where you can sit quietly watching the carp in the pond or just contemplating life. It is well maintained.
Nice enough for a peaceful 15 minute walk or maybe a photo shoot. There’s a cool looking play park for children there. Not much else to say.
If you want to get away from the city these gardens are ideal to visit. Tranquil and peaceful they have a lovely feel. Very pretty and well kept, worth a visit if you are near.

Very nice place to wander around or sit on the grass for an hour or so. It's not too big but is kept very well and is definitely relaxing. There's terrapins and carp in the water and a zen garden with a buddha included. It's about a 20 minute walk from the capitol square and not

It is so easy to walk around Toulouse and we approached the Japanese Gardens from Pont Neuf, along the La Brien canal. The gardens are at the rear of the main park area and were beautiful. The weather was a little grey and overcast and it was early in the season. I imagine the
Pretty space very well kept and inviting but could use some seats for those who wish to relax in the garden. Sitting on the grass is not permitted.

A curious garden - designed in the "Japanese Style" by the Toulouse parks department - with some features "protected" from visitors by caution tape! A nice place to visit if you are in the area, but not a full day destination.
This Large japonese garden was used for wedding pictures. Nice fenced of area in the surrounding park.

What a nice surprise in the middle of city, there are great walks all around the park, bridges, fountain, streams, and cafe with delicious crepes, wine, coffee and much more. Great place for a picnic1
It is a nice garden for kids to play around and watch the fishes in the pond, nothing extra-ordinary about the garden. There is a small play area for kids behind the garden. No entrance fee.
Very beautiful parc a little bit outside the city center of Toulouse (only 1-2 metro stops or a 15-20 minute walk). Beautiful garden and nice atmosphere!
This is place of peace, calm and tranquillity. The place has a red bridge over a little river, koi carp, siting areas and walks with some lovely plants and flowers. Well worth a visit

Lovely garden but there were quite a lot of people milling around so not easy to appreciate its beauty and contemplating experience. It has all the ingredients of a Japanese garden. Best to visit in spring when the cherry blossoms are in full bloom.
It is that kind of place that makes you forget you are in the centre of a city. Beautiful and peaceful. Lots of green space.

The garden is secure and clean. All trees and plants are very well taken care of. But it’s quite small so there’s no need to plan hours to see it. I would recommend to buy some food to go and just eat at the garden while you relax. The red bridge is the most important thing in

Whenever wishing to have some time to go away from the rush of the city life, the Japanese garden is an oasis of calmness. In the morning you can see people meditating or just quietly walking around its narrow paths. It is well kept and the Tea House in the center of it offers

Loved the garden, well maintained and interesting history of former mayor of Toulouse with Japan and in particular, Kyoto. Very nice stone display, red bridge and Japanese plants including bamboo - very peaceful
I fell in love with the quietness of this garden. I wad specially impressed with the Koi carps. They are huge and don't seem to mind the frozen ester of the lake at all.
Very cute place, with a red bridge, and pavillion. Great place for photos as well. There is a monument of a zen master. Spend some time relaxing here.

The park was already very nice but the japanese garden was beautiful and calm. The red brigde and the little water place turn the garden into a really relaxed and peaceful spot. If you wanna take some time off from the big city in the big city - go there and sit in the sun. Its
Title says it all. Nice break from hectic Toulouse. Found it by accident when staying at hotel next door.
A lovely little gem into Toulouse and the array of Autumn colours were beautiful. Interesting wildlife. Worth a visit!

During our weekend in Toulouse it was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city to have a couple of hours out. From the city centre, we took the metro to the closest station and then walked to the gardens. The weather was beautiful and as it was November there weren’t
4th visit for us but first in Autumn. Definitely worth a quick visit if in Toulouse and not too busy. Nice for a respite from shopping and sightseeing and truly beautiful.
This garden is hidden behind a larger public park.This park was quiet and very pleasant. If you're in the area make sure to drop by!
Nice park, close to other parks and to the metro station. Offers a calm walk, specially at the end of the day.

A tranquil haven in a busy city, lovely spot to wander around and admire the Japanese style of pruning and lovely little lake with carp. Good children's playground nearby too. Allow an hour and cover up/wear repellent if you're prone to insect bites.
Very nice Japanese garden in middle of the city. Great place to rest or just walk. There is a cat who has an elegant house.

A very strange little place in the middle of toulouse. Would really reccomend a visit. It has fantastic displays of Japanese architecture and just overall really worth a visit. Only downside is that is was a bit dirty when we got there.
Quiet and beautiful hideaway in an otherwise very stony city. Don't sit on the grass, the park guard will tell you off in a very French and not so nice way.

An opportunity to see a range of planting and some design features. But too small to be peaceful. So, a worthwhile concept but execution flawed. Following another reviewer's suggestion, on leaving the park I walked along the canal. However, heavy traffic made that less than
Loved the Japanese house by the lake - lovely Acer trees. An oasis in the middle of the city - well worth a visit for at least an hour.
Lovely gardens to sit in, did close at 6 but able to sit by lake after closing, nice to see the koi in the water and even saw a terrepin basking in the water, nice clean park and well maintained

If you happen to be in the park that this garden is a part of, it's fine to walk through, but it's not worth a visit otherwise. Better still, leave the park from the north side facing the Canal du Midi and stroll along there. We saw loads of ducks and two otters enjoying the

A pleasant little garden in Toulouse.It is not going to take your breathe away However, to walk around and have some nice chill time it's perfect. We took a little picnic and had a lovely 20 mins there. A lovely little Japanese Garden.

The Japonais garden is small but relaxing. It has a nice pagoda and a pond, but there is a wide field which has nothing in it yet. A little disappointing since it is a little far away from the center of the city.

Very well kept gardens within the park - which had it's fare share of local drunks in it though this area was very well looked after. It was just unusual to suddenly find the lovely spot in the city - with a bridge, pavilion and zen garden and pond with turtles thrown in. Nice
After reading the reviews we came out of our way to see this garden. It's a garden within a garden and there wasn't a lot there that I would class as Japanese. The water in the pond was filthy too!

We walked around the park for around 30 mins. We are from NZ so use to lots of grass so was nice to swap the city for the park for a while. It was a nice garden but not all of it was very well maintained - at least to what we are use to back home. The photo shows a nice part
Beautiful place to visit when you are in Toulouse. They maintained the garden very well. Although it is a bit small it is still worth to visit it.

I went there with my girlfriend and had a walk in this wonderful parc. There was informations about feng shui and also a very nice place to look at. The place is beautiful and is perfect for a romantic stroll in a calm place.

This is a beautiful park with quite large Japanese Garden in it, perfect for a family visit or a picnic with friends, tranquil despite many people around. There's plenty of benches and grass to sit around and take a break from the day of work or sightseeing. It's easy to get to

A well designed garden with a good variety of plantings, trees and settings. Would have given five stars but the pond seemed murky and in need of aeration - it may be misplaced, but I felt concerned for the well-being of the Koi and terrapins.

Very nice walking spot, as well as the perfect place to just sit down at one of the many benches available to just relax for a while. The are some spectacular trees and plants, as well as different decoration in typical japanese style. Definitely a must see in Toulouse!
The gardens are generally well maintained and are a quiet spot away from the busy city and square. Also plenty of wildlife to look out for!

We visited the garden whilst out walking along the Canal du Midi. Along the route of the canal, we reached the Jardin Compans-Caffarelli and detoured into the park to visit the Jardin Japonais (Japanese Garden). The Japanese Garden is in the centre of the larger Jardin
So pleasant to walk around or sit for while in the lovely tendered gardens - so quiet in this busy place. Some huge Koi in the spacious pond. Teenagers even liked it!

A really beautiful place in the Pink city, really calm, it's always a pleasure to come there with friends ! After a good ramen at St Michel street on wednesday, I usualy come with friends to see the little cat who live in the "Jardin Japonais" and have a great time !
This place is so beautiful and tranquil and definitely worth a visit. I went three times on my 5 day visit to Toulouse. Very beautiful a lovely place to unwind and enjoy the sun.

Visiting friends were desperate to visit the garden so we made a picnic and trotted up to Campans. I took a back seat so they could practise their French. No signs to help find the place once in the 'outside' park and when we got inside and sat down, we were told to get off the

if you have been to a real japanese garden, you would know that there's a good resemblance which is commendable. the wooden pavilion was nicely built. it wasn't big but quite cosy. the pond though was pretty murky and almost completely covered by algae. hardly able to see the
It was supposed to be a calm place to be in but with a kids park behind its impossible. Also not many spaces to enjoy that jardin. Not that great of a visit.

It is a lovely space, but smaller than I had hoped and even though it is set within another path it is not an oasis of calm. the lake, tea house bridge area is lovely but the gravel garden is not well maintained. It is a bit off the beaten tourist track in the city, but as the
Small but very beautiful Japanese garden. Really a good place for a short walk and enjoy the cite and place.

Quiet... the feel of traveling far away to japan. The best place to relax from city life and just enjoy the nature. The trees were blooming and the pink leaves were making a dream look a like day. Ps: check the signs and prohibitions. It's a strick quiet place, and no bikes

The Japanese Garden is within a much bigger park. It is only open from 8.30 - 3pm. Our first visit was after three and the gates to the garden was locked. Quite a few of us were disappointed and there were no signs to say what the opening times only that visiting was limited.
It's quite nice. It's not easy to find. That said, where else would you find a Japanese garden in a city, urban environment? Have you got one. Nice oasis. Bide a while. Well done, Toulouse

We wanted to visit The Jardin Japonais on Friday 7 July. Unfortunately, it was closed. The Japanese garden in the middle of public park is surrounded by a fence and all the gates were closed to our disappointment. I don't know a cause, no info provided.

Went here on Sunday having purchased sandwiches and drinks from a supermarket for an improvised picnic. The Japanese garden is worth a visit to see the artificial pond with Koi Carp and turtles swimming in the muddy water. The winding paths and little bridge certainly invoke the
You enter the garden and the time stops. It's calm although there were many people at the time we went there. You can just sit or lie on the ground and relax. It's very nice to take photos too

I was walking around Toulouse as I was to early to go in to my hostel when I came across the Japanese garden it was a pleasant surprise. The building it self looked very authentic as well as the choice of plants that was present even thought the site is very small there was a
Great to wander through. The whole park is quite nice, which convenient if you rock up expecting to see this one and it's shut (not open all the time).

The Japanese garden was interesting and quite calm compared to the rest of Toulouse. The walls and the lake were not very well maintained. The creators of the garden had clearly done a lot of research into Japanese garden traditions and there were accompany descriptions about

We had spare time before going on a tour. The lady in the tourist office had recommended a visit. It's a lovely tranquil place, well maintained, plenty of seating in the shade, and an extensive planting of unusual specimens.
Spent an entire day in this hidden hen. So serene and tranquil, loved sitting in the little temple watching the coy Carps and turtles. Very beautiful
A beautiful and relaxing garden, only 20 min walk from the center. Definitely a must-see in Toulouse!
The garden provides a splendid respite from the busy city and the mid-day heat. One small warning is to stay off the grass!

I was in the Centre de Congrès Pierre Baudis and I had some time so I took a walk in the park. It is a big park. The interesting part of the park is a location dedicated to the japanese culture and tradition. There is a japanese building, with some statue and bridge. The lake in
What a garden, sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo Green, big and beautiful trees Very long trees, there is also a small beautiful lake and Japanese house, kids play area and wonderful pure fresh air
It was a total surprise, one of the most beautiful and relaxing parks I've ever been. It actually looks like be in Japan.
Beautiful...tranquil and peaceful. Very well maintained with some interesting features. The perfect place to chill out
Would recommend visiting here for a short walk around. It's really picturesque and a nice place to spend up to half an hour max. It isn't huge so don't plan on spending a lot of time there!

in the middle of a park in Toulouse is this quiet Japanese garden with lake and bridge and lovely plants. there is also lots of places for picnic and great play area for kids. with small cafes for coffee and ice cream and even a beer.

A well maintained place. The park within which the garden is located is very serene too. Would surely recommend if you have an hour or two.

Absolutely loved visiting this garden. Ideal for taking loads of photographs and it's free entry. Sunshine did add to the attraction
Nice place to just chill and just sit n relax, or even to sit on a ench next to a random person at lunch break lol

Hidden oasis in toulouse, good place for sunday morning jogging. Bring your cam coz they have some instagrammable spots too
Beautiful and the display is Very informative. Lovely trees and koi in the lake. Good place for wedding photos too apparently

A very nice place to relax and watch the fish in the pools and take in the views of the bonsai trees.

Great spot to laze away a sunny Sunday afternoon. People picnicking on the lawns and Salsa dancing in the gazebo. Great plants, landscaping and a lovely family feel. Very pleasant.

A beautiful Japanese garden near to the city centre in Toulouse. Whilst it was busy as it was patrimony weekend, it was a beautifully serene spot for contemplation and rest. Well worth a visit if time!

A bit away from city center but definitely worth to visit, beautiful garden architecture, nice place to take a rest during city tour.
This garden is located within a larger public park. It is well tended and a nice place to relax, read, and reflect.

Must see in toulouse. You can lie around for hours or simply pop in for 10 minutes. But add it to your route.

the weather was very good when we saw jardin japonaise. it is not very big but worth visiting with its refreshing aura.
A beauty park where you can have a good time for a boring Sunday... it's not too big but is big enough to have a great evening with family or even alone.

Very calm jardin to relax. There are really beutiful plants and flowers. The water in the pond was very muddy and we couldn't really see the koi fishes. Otherwise a very nice little park and a must see in Toulouse.

Some beautiful planting here and a very authentic Japanese feel. Loved the classic red bridge. We spent an hour here but could have been a lot longer.

Small but lovely half an hour spent walking around this place. Quite difficult finding the entrance, as its in the middle of another park and surrounded by trees, but was worth it. Love the teahouse by the lake and the little bridge. Great for a little relaxation!
For those used to English gardens, this is nothing special.....but this is in the heart of the office district of toulouse, so a really lovely place to eat lunch on a hot day

text.wiki:
The Basilica of Saint-Sernin (Occitan: Basilica de Sant Sarnin) is a church in Toulouse, France, the former abbey church of the Abbey of Saint-Sernin or St Saturnin. Apart from the church, none of the abbey buildings remain. The current church is located on the site of a previous basilica of the 4th century which contained the body of Saint Saturnin or Sernin, the first bishop of Toulouse in c. 250. Constructed in the Romanesque style between about 1080 and 1120, with construction continuing thereafter, Saint-Sernin is the largest remaining Romanesque building in Europe, if not the world. The church is particularly noted for the quality and quantity of its Romanesque sculpture. In 1998 the basilica was added to the UNESCO World Heritage Sites under the description: World Heritage Sites of the Routes of Santiago de Compostela in France.


== History ==

The abbey of Saint-Sernin was an ancient foundation. St. Sylvius, bishop of Toulouse, began construction of the basilica towards the end of the 4th century.Its importance increased enormously after Charlemagne (r. 768-800) donated a quantity of relics to it, as a result of which it became an important stop for pilgrims on their way to Santiago de Compostela, and a pilgrimage location in its own right. The size of the current building and the existence of an ambulatory may reflect the need to accommodate increasing numbers of pilgrims.
The difficulty of determining an accurate chronology for the construction of Saint-Sernin and the completion of its sculpture has given rise to numerous problems. At least as early as the 1010s, Bishop Pierre Roger had set aside a portion of the offerings to Saint-Sernin for an eventual rebuilding of the Carolingian church. During the decade of the 1070s and by 1080 at the latest, the canons of Saint-Sernin had accepted the rule of St. Augustine and had placed themselves under the direct control of the Holy See. Nevertheless, there are only two firm dates that bear directly on the church itself and even these involve certain difficulties. On May 24, 1096, Pope Urban II dedicated the altar of the still largely incomplete building. Although there have been numerous attempts to determine the point that construction had reached at this time, the most that can be said with certainty is that 1096 is a firm terminus ante quem. That is, construction must have begun at least several years before that date.
The second firm date is July 3, 1118, the death of St. Raymond Gayrard, canon and provost of the chapter. A 15th-century life of the saint states that he took charge of the building after part of the church had been completed and that by the time of his death he had "brought the walls all the way around up to the completion of the windows..." Unfortunately, the life was written much later, some three hundred years after the events it describes, and since at least three different Raymonds were involved in the building of the church, the biographer may have confused elements from the lives of all three.
At any rate, whenever started, it appears that construction of the church did not progress continuously through to completion, for there is physical evidence of several interruptions in construction. The literary evidence cited above indicates that construction proceeded from east to west and, indeed, it appears that the earliest part of the exterior walls is the southern, lower part of the ambulatory and its corresponding radiating chapels. The walls in this section are built of brick and stone, with a higher proportion of stone than elsewhere in the building. As construction proceeded, it was clearly marked by an increasing proportion of brick, the characteristic building material of Toulouse. While there is basic agreement on the starting point, interpretation of the subsequent archeological evidence is subject to varying opinions. The earliest systematic examinations, after the restoration of Viollet-le-Duc, concluded that there had been three major building campaigns.More recent observations have concluded that there were four major building campaigns. The earliest section begins with the apse and includes the chevet and all of the transept below the level of the gallery, including the Porte des Comtes in the south face of the transept. The second stage is marked by the walls of the transept being completed with alternating courses of brick and stone. This change is also paralleled by a change in the style of the interior decorated capitals. This break is most evident in the transept buttresses, which change from solid stone at the bottom to bands of brick and stone at the top, a change which occurs at various levels around the transept but generally about the level of the gallery floor. There then follows another break between the eastern portion of the church – including the transept and the first few bays of the nave itself – and the rest of the nave. The alternating courses of brick and stone give way to a predominantly brick technique with stone quoins and stone window frames. This third campaign includes the wall enclosing the entire nave, including the western entrance and ends just below the gallery windows. During the fourth phase, the remainder of the nave was completed in brick with almost no stone.
The plan of the abbey church here was also used in the construction of the cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, "begun in 1082, too direct a copy to have been done by any but Saint-Sernin's own architect or his favored pupil", but finished much earlier.In 1860, Eugène Viollet-le-Duc restored the church, but his changes are currently being removed to restore the original appearance.


== Features ==

Despite being called a basilica, Saint-Sernin's deviates from the basilica plan of early Christian architecture in a few ways. It is much larger compared to earlier churches, measuring 104m in length. It is also constructed mostly of brick. The building is in the form of a crucifix. The ceilings are vaulted, unlike many of the earlier churches. Saint-Sernin's contains radiating chapels which were used to display important relics. Another deviation from the earlier Christian churches is the addition of an ambulatory, a walkway that goes around the nave and side aisles to allow for viewing of the radiating chapels (which could be done while mass was being held without interrupting the ceremony). For these and other reasons, Saint-Sernin's is often said to follow the "pilgrimage plan" instead of the traditional basilica plan.


=== Exterior ===
On the exterior, the bell tower, standing directly over the transept crossing, is the most visible feature. It is divided into five tiers, of which the lower three, with Romanesque arches, date from the 12th century and the upper two from the 13th century (circa 1270). The spire was added in the 15th century. The bell tower is slightly inclined towards the west direction, which is why from certain standpoints the bell tower roof, whose axis is perpendicular to the ground, appears to be inclined to the tower itself.
The chevet is the oldest part of the building, constructed in the 11th century, and consists of nine chapels, five opening from the apse and four in the transepts.
The exterior is additionally known for two doorways, the Porte des Comtes and the Porte Miègeville. Above the Porte des Comtes is a depiction of Lazarus and Dives. Dives in hell can be seen above the central column. The doorway gets its name from a nearby alcove in which the remains of four Counts of Toulouse are kept. The Porte Miègeville is known for its elaborate sculpture above the entrance: the ascending Christ, surrounded by superb angels, is the central figure on one of the oldest and most beautiful tympanums in Romanesque architecture (circa 1115).

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


=== Interior ===
The interior of the basilica measures 115 x 64 x 21 meters, making it vast for a Romanesque church. The central nave is barrel vaulted; the four aisles have rib vaults and are supported by buttresses. Directly under the tower and the transept is a marble altar, consecrated by Pope Urban II in 1096 and designed by Bernard Gelduin.
As well as Saint Saturnin, Saint Honoratus is also buried here. The crypt contains the relics of many other saints.
The basilica also contains a large three-manual Cavaillé-Coll organ built in 1888. Together with the Cavaillé-Coll instruments at Saint-Sulpice in Paris and the Church of St. Ouen, Rouen, it is considered to be one of the most important organs in France.

Spiritual and educative visit of Saint Sernin. Visited several times and discover something new each time; being a gem of history and spiritual depth. Miss it already!

This is a beautiful Basilica and not far from Place du Capitole. Mass schedules are posted and not to be missed.

Stunning building whether you're religious or not. Free to enter too. The square is also nice place to have breakfast or a coffee.

I am not a lover of what goes on in these place, but find the buildings fascinating and beautiful. This is no exception.

A must to be seen for the architectural record, the history where some of the "Franc" Counts of Toulouse are buried there. The Counts of Toulouse, once richer and more powerful than the King of France. Also if curious find the corner stone that was brought back from the Solomon

If you will be spending time in this area, this church and the explanatory signs (in several languages) are a good introduction to the significance of religious pilgrimages to the towns and villages around. Plus the church is a beautiful creation! The crypt was closed on the

If you do not tire of seeing churches in Europe then this is one for the memory card. Entry to the main basilica is free and worth it for its amazing size and standing...and if you pay 2.5 euro you can get up close and personal in the Crypts and Ambulatory where there is housed
The idea that this has survived is amazing. I am very glad that the neighborhood around the church is being re-constructed.
Very peaceful, lots of history and nice gardens, worth a visit and the basilica is still functioning.
This place is stunning inside. It's definitely worth a visit and also worth going to see the crypts too. The ceilings are beautifully painted too

Fairly average basilique, especially having just come from Narbonne and Carcassonne, where there are much more impressive buildings. More modern if you prefer that kind of thing though and it is free, which is a bonus. They have about the 'great organ', but i also didn't think

A very nice basilique.a very old church with beautiful stained glass windows..a quaint walk through the old part of town brings you to the old city centre..lots of shops.and cafes...lovely cobbled streets.just walk around and enjoy..
Ancient Basillique with interesting crypt. The main alter has a beautiful large baldacchino. If your lucky, the sounds of the organ might be heard.
Really beautiful exterior but the interior is just as breathtaking. Take a stroll around the inside to see the beautiful windows and ceiling.
Beautiful building. Stunning tower. If you can visit at the moment there is a haunting photographic display for Easter
Very unique chapel with intricate work on the facade. It also has a lovely square with a fountain. Worth visiting on a walking tour of the city.
This is an outstanding example of Romanesque architecture and definitely worth visiting in Toulouse.
Was visiting our daughter (an international student) and doing a tour of Toulouse. Well worth a visit. Also the Croissant/bread hop nearby is excellent

There is a gorgeous painted ceiling at the far end of the nave but you can't get any closer unless you go through a gate. Others have mentioned paying to see the crypt and thus you get a closer look at it, but it seems no one was around for me to get tickets (on a Saturday
From the outside, it looks like a red-brick factory. Inside, it's not too impressive until you (pay and) go through to the cloisters, which have a far more tranquil, meditative feel.
The Basilica is amazing and definitely worth visiting. A truly impressive building, created with skill, precision and style

This is an amazing place to visit, such a huge building! It is free to enter but if you want to go down to the crypt then it's €2.50. When we went there was some restoration work going on which was a little noisy.
The basilica is phenomenal, not only because of its size, architecture, paintings, and history, but also for its huge crypt that houses many reliquaries. Audio guide is available.

Do take the time to see this spectacular church. Towards the back on the left, there is a ticket office where you can buy a ticket for the ambulatory the church. This is really worth the small fee. Then you admitted to the area of the church with the most beautiful altars and

Wonderful interior ! The stained glass windows, fantastic organ (being tuned when I visited), majestic ceiling are really something. They've done a good job of restoring inside and out. Restoration works on the main entrance are still ongoing. Was happy to be able to finally
Well worth visiting and the ambulatory and crypts are a must. The outside of the building is also interesting for it architecture.

Somewhat plain inside compared to some but it had a somberness that I think I missing in some ancient churches-cum-tourist attractions. My wife and I toured, left for lunch, and came back to tour the crypt, but unless we took a very wrong turn, we were a bit disappointed with

This is a vast and complex basilica on the site of a very early bishop's grave. Started sometime in the 11th century, it grew and grew taking a beautiful Romanesque brick form. Inside, the apse has a set of radiating chapels called chevets. This amazing building dominates this
I last visited this when I lived in the city some 30 years ago and it was in a parlous state. Glad to see on my return that it had received some TLC and is a magnificent cathedral once again

I see why this is rated #1 thing the see here. Worth seeing if you like visiting churches. My guess is 45 minutes to 90 is more than sufficient. Lots of public parking around, costing 3 euros for a few hours. Access to view the area under the dome costs a couple euro

This was one of my favorite places in Toulouse, the architecture of this church is impressive, its height and decorations deserve being observed carefully. Don't miss the gardens and the chapel, they worth being visited too. I spent like 2 hours observing all the parts of this
Amazing visit but watch out the mornings when there is a market as you cannot enjoy the basilique that much. Recommend by night.
European Biggest roman style Church. A true architectural master piece. If you have been to Ho Chi Minh you may find the equivalent in Viêt Nam. A piece of history. Please take the time to visit.

Even on a damp, miserable day this church is inspiring. On the outside it is impressive, with an unusual design and set in a very pretty part of town. Inside is beautiful because of its simplicity and well worth spending at least 20 minutes walking around. Unfortunately the

It was quite an experience to see a medieval basilica which was not damaged during WWII. I can only recommend a visit to soak up the atmosphere and for history buffs read up on its construction and how it fared over the centuries.
one of those huge buildings you can see from almost every point in the city! The tower is very beautiful! The trueth is that I liked it more from the outside than from the inside (its very simple).

Important place on the map of the city. Nicely preserved building from 11th century with some later additions. Most of visit is for free but I recommend to pay (not too expensive) to visit crypts and ambulatory. Small folders in few languages available.
Most of my travels in Europe involve seeing beautiful cathedrals and this is no exception. It's different to others being quiet modest in decor but is a must! Beautiful yet elegant!

A beautiful environment with a great sense of calm. A simply styled basilica with and interesting history. We were fascinated with this area - there was a flea market outside full of North African and Middle Eastern vendors. It felt a little unsettling as they were all men - no
Great place to visit. Basilique is located in city centre, just 5 minutes of walk from main central square. From architecture, relics and tombs, many interesting things to see. Worth a visit!
A bit quirky but well worth coming to see. A shame you can't go up the central tower, which is quite distinctive

The basilique is beautiful, just the architecture itself was worth it, but also it truly inspired peace and some desire for introspection. Unfortunately at the very moment I visited the access to the tombs was closed for some renewal. The organ started playing majestically, this

I think it is the most impressive church in town, part of the route for the pilgrims os Saint-Jacques de Compostela (there are special hours for pilgrims arrivals). The church has relics of several saints and is absolutely beautiful and a special atmosphere, hard to describe.
A quite unusual church with an interesting tower. Internally its quite clear of clutter and therefore good to wander round. We enjoyed the visit as part of a day in Toulouse
This is a big cathedral located about 5 min. away from the Capitol. It is worth visiting by your self, but having a tour guide will change your perspective on the place.

Impressive in size both externally and more so internally. Historically important to the city. If you can catch a service do so - the organ sounds magnificent. You pay 2.5 euros to enter the crypt and it is worth this small fee. It is not far from a stop on the metro (Line B).
An impressive church. The wall paintings are very interesting and well-preserved. Unlike a lot of churches, one can take photographs of everything. Highly recommended.
This church is truly magnificent. It is well worth visiting and also welcomes pilgrims on the Camino de Santiago
St. S. was built from the Toulouse red brick and was very large and impressive inside and out. If you like Romanesque, this is for you.
The Basilica is in an area close the the university. Its off a side street so may need a little effort to find. Actually a stop on the French part of the Camino.
Even by French church standards, this is a very impressive building. And, along the Rue Taur, there is another church that is very easy to miss that is also worth a visit.

This is the former abbey church of St. Sernin located on the site of a previous basilica of the 4th century which contained the body of the first bishop of Toulouse in c.250. It was constructed in the Romanesque style 1080-1120 and is the largest remaining Romanesque building in
The place was historically stunning and the architecture was so beautiful. The pipe organ which we can listen to the concert on Sunday impressed me also.

As an art historian,I wanted to visit St. Sernin. It is remarkable. However, what I did not expect that enhanced the experience was to visit when there was a funeral mass. The music and liturgy ( and I am not Catholic) was so moving in this very old and very well preserved

Both from the outside and the inside this is a magnificent church, decorated with splendid statuary. The crypt, which costs 2.50 euros admission, contains a number of fine bas reliefs, including a wonderful 11th-century Christ in Majesty. From the point of view of art history,
It is a beautiful church, a few steps away from the Place du Capitole: not only is the stroll there quite please, but so is the view of the building itself.

It is as a pellegrin that I visited this immense and beautiful piece of architecture and history and it is with great pleasure that I took the time to take a long tour by myself although I could have used a guide on site if wanted. If you visit Toulouse, St Sernin is a must!
If you are visiting Toulouse and not visiting monumental sites you are not filling the visitor card. This is one of the Must See items.
Interesting red brick former Abbey with frescoes and impressive Nave. Best visited early in the morning before tour parties arrive and whiz around the aisles.

This is a wonderful piece of architecture, inside and out. The number of iconic figuerines sculpted around the altar are incredible! The whole work must be forty feet high. You really feel steeped in the Catholic tradition, and we spent several quiet minutes just looking at the

This is a fine example of a cathedral done in the Romanesque style (round arches and vaults) predating the gothic period of cathedral construction more commonly used in northern France and England. Definitely worth a visit to compare the smaller fenestration and interior natural

This stunning church in Toulouse has to be one of the most beautiful I've ever seen. Unfortunately I went inside on a Sunday during which a large mass was taking place so did not get the chance to see inside the crypt or really take in the splendour of the place properly.

We were cutting through town and stumbled on Saint Sernin, we did not get chance to look inside but from the outside it looked truly fantastic, would loved to have spent more time there and I bet inside is truly wonderful.
A magnificent example of Romanesque architecture and said to be the largest Romanesque church in Europe.

Not expecting anything so special, we were delighted by how much there is to see in this magnificent building which is the largest Norman-style church in the world. It is definitely worth paying the few euros charge to see behind the main altar and visit the crypt. The church

This is a shrine to a 5th century martyr (St. Saturnin) whose resting place became a highly popular pilgrimage site. The building is huge and impressive, with interesting things to see inside, including tombs in the crypt (fee). Probably the best sight in Toulouse. Nearby

Oh how disappointing that visit was. No idea why it is no. 1 of things to do. I suppose you could say it's large, but apart from that it's very uninspiring. It looks like all the walls and columns have been washed, except for a very few that are still vaguely decorated.

Having enjoyed reading about the history of this cathedral it was quite nice to see it in the flesh. As one of the largest remaining Romanesque buildings in Europe it's well worth a look. Try to visit on a day with good weather as the blue skies make for an awesome backdrop. We
A vaulting ceiling and a basilica with an interesting history. Worth seeing and relatively easy to get to as most of the Toulouse sights are within walking distance of each other.

Our hotel recommended we visit as this Basilique has lots of history. When we walked in Mass had just started (Sunday) so we stayed. It was all in French but could follow (with our very limited French) what the reading, songs were. Lost it with the homily, didn't matter, the
This is a beautiful building and worth walking to. On Sundays the area around the basilica provides space for many stalls alternating between the flea market, regular markets and brocantes.
nice place, lot of history, nice soroundings. easy to reach, nice place to check while in tolouse. :)
The Basilique is nice from outside but inside there's nothing special. So we recommend to visit only when you have it on your way (what you definitely gonna have ;) )

A little disappointed to find it totally surrounded by an uncoordinated flea market - goods sprawled across the pavement and hung on the railings - which seemed completely out of place, especially with a funeral taking place inside at the same time. We couldn't really understand
Some Cathedrals in Europe try hard to wow its visitors. A very few seem to have somehow attained more of a sincere spiritual impact. This is one of them.

We slipped into the side door and waited for our eyes to adjust. The Basilique Saint-Sernin invoked awe with its flickering votives, golden altar, and vaulted majesty. The choir loft is elaborately carved and the organ pipes in the rear of the chamber are remote but

For a cathedral it was rather underwhelming inside. It was much more stunning outside. It was plain inside and the pews looked very uncared for. Perhaps they are hoping for an injection of cash to renovate the place. There were guides available and if you are religious it was a

The Basilique, set in the middle of the attractive Place St Sernin , stands imposing and majestic and oozing with history. It was constructed between 1080 and 1120 and became an important stop for pilgrims on the route to the Santiago de Compostella and would probably have
This is a beautiful church. There is a lot to see there...also a lot to see along the rue du taur. Highly worth visiting if you are local

This very large church is one of the oldest in France and truly awe inspiring. It is dedicated to a 3rd century bishop sent to the area by Rome. Under no circumstances should anyone visit Toulouse without seeing it. It is located less than 10 minutes by foot from the main square.
Although it is obviously a rebuilt of the original cathedral, it blends well with the rest of the city and can be seen from a distance.

Given its rating on Tripadvisor as the top attraction, I was expecting to be awesome. The tower and exterior of the church was interesting but I thought the inside was not well maintained or stocked, although there were guides available to show you around I didn't see any

The Sunday market around the basilica spreading right out to boulevard de Strasbourg where the food and cakes are is a must if you are here. Lots of bits and bobs I've not seen before, leather sold by the yard, trinkets and avoid the cheap cigarettes! The Basilique is very

Spent around 2 hrs here on a Saturday. Make sure you visit the crypt: small charge. What more can be said: if you like the history, calm, and architecture of great churches and cathedrals then you need to go.

Supposed to be the world's largest aromatic style basilica. Late stage though and gothic elements (even the crypt!). However, awesome architecture and enough to stun at, among it early age relics of apostle Simon et al.

You can see why this magnificent building 'pulls in the crowds'. I dare say that it is the same reason that it was constructed in the fist place. This really is a breathtaking place to visit, worship in and just admire the architecture. For all the magnificence this
Huge basilica with a very busy flea market on Sundays. Possible to visit the crypt for a small fee. Nice cafés around.

One of the biggest and best-preserved Romanesque churches of the south, a giant among piligrimage churches. OK, I studies the building in college, couldn't wait to see it when I spent a week or so in Toulouse thirty years later, and now, thirty years after that, saw it after
Really beautiful church in the middle of the city. The church is certainly worth the visit and you might be lucky to hear the choir rehearse while you are there.

The size of the basilica is impressive. I found it to be more beautiful from the outside than the inside. It has an interesting architecture especially with the tower and the brick-red tower. We didn't visit the crypt and we only made a short tour inside and then out!

Travelling through France and Spain can leave one with church fatigue but this one is worth a visit. My first time in Toulouse which is a lovely city and the Basilica adds to the city's appeal. Lovely both inside and out.
Very big and gorgeous (in old times I think) church, I can't say that it is something special but can be visited once. I found interesting that it was made from ordinary bricks in some parts :)

Saint-Sernin is a huge and beautiful basilica to visit in Toulouse. The basilica is well-located and the architecture is amazing with many details. One of the most wonderful basilics that I had the chance to visit in France.
I was enjoying the ceremony on Sunday morning in this church. Very beautiful hystorical building with many sculptures and pictures and colourful vitrages.
One of the most beautiful basilics to visit in the south of France. The large stained glasses give impressive colours from the inside.
This place was overrated. Would recommend Les Jacobins over this if you're short on time. The spire looks nice on the outside, but can't be accessed on the inside.
This is a very nice church and I think one of the most visited in Toulouse.Builded in roman style with a beatiful bell tower and many chapels worths a visit free of charge.
well worth a visit, very interesting and lots to see, as you stroll around the very pleasant old town of Toulouse

I visited this place on Sunday. Initially I went to see the church and I visited also very nice church. After my visit I also did shopping around this place. On Saturday and Sunday many people come here for shopping. It's kind of old market where all sellers come in thee Van
A must visit if in this stunning city. Well wort spending an hour looking around the church. The architecture is superb and there are multilingual guide options.

This is an interesting church but you have to pay to see the relics and boxes that hold them. I think the boxes are way more interesting than the relics. The best place for relics is the Residence in Munich. These boxes made me think of something Indiana Jones would have been
This church is on the UNESCO list and is a must see item in Toulouse, it is both amazing and beutiful
Reasonably well maintained basilica in a nice, serene surroundings. Indeed peaceful and divine experience
Beautiful example of Romanesque architecture with a typical toulousain style towerbell. Superb inside, try to visit the crypt for a small fee.
Elegant, impressive, echoes within and without on Sundays the buzz of the flea market or brocante all around. A Toulouse landmark worth visiting

Best is to arrive before 6pm so you can visit a part for a small entrance fee with access downstairs to lot of relics and "chasses" which are containers used for relics transportation. Some of the people working there are very passionate about this basilica history and would be
Unusual church, with a great history. Do not miss the cloister. Tis style is not my favourite, but to each their own
Beautiful and historic destination in Toulouse. For all - religious and those seeking a piece of French history. Quaint outdoor setting as well.
Massive building which exudes class, tradition and history. Fantastic art work. Best to visit before the mass of tourists arrive.
A beautiful structure inside and out. On Saturday and Sunday we strolled around the flea market surrounding the cathedral soaking up the sights and sounds.
Georgeous basilique, one of the oldest ones in Europe. Although the entrance to the crypt is paid, it is definitely worth the extra money.
The basilica is amazing and the visit is great. The area around the basilica is beautiful and inside, the church is very interesting. No wonder this is the number 1 attraction in Toulouse.

Just stunning, nothing less! Beautiful church tower and exterior look, even more amazing decor inside! Many bars, cafes and restaurants near by. Free entry, but there is little fee of 2 euro should you wish to see the altar too.
Beautiful basilica that has to be seen. The ceilings and walls are beautiful as are the windows. Literature is excellent.
This is a must visit if in Toulouse. Plenty of history explained in French and English but mainly just worth seeing for how nice a building it is both inside and out

This church is one of many around Toulouse but is one of the larger, more well known of the city. Set at the end of Rue de Taur, where it is said St. Stephen was dragged down tied to a bull, it has wonderful architecture. Once a regular stop for pilgrims en route to St. Jaques

beautiful cathedral for its history, rich and mysterious , its location , its summer concerts , to visit, alone, with family , in a group , we feel impregnated of great tranquility. its free except. Free outside the crypt treasure.

The size, grandeur and history of this Basilica make this a must stop to enjoy. It is recommended to take pictures from the east/northeast side to capture the entire Basilica. While the stop can likely be brief the views and moments to take make this a worthwhile stop.

The rich history and religion here are overwhelming. A must see if you're in Toulouse. We enjoyed our visit immensely. The only thing that would have made it better for us was a guidebook or audio in English.

Basilique St-Sernin, a massive structure and the largest remaining Romanesque building in Europe. It is difficult to fully capture the immensity of this church due to its tremendous size, both from the outside as well as within. Stained glass windows alone are worth a visit.

A UNESCO World Heritage Site, this largest remaining Romanesque building in Europe was Southwest France's most important stop for pilgrims on the Way of St. James. It glows pink with the famous brickwork of Toulouse. Its marvelous stained glass looks uncannily modern. Its 12th
The bricks are one thousand years old!! It is a marvel to see and to photographe. Very easy acces from the center of historic Toulouse.
Stunning old church with gorgeous stained glass windows and artwork. Really beautiful and worth a visit if you are in Toulouse and enjoy a bit of history.

A fabulous building that has a serene & calming atmosphere. It invites one to light a candle in remembrance of a loved one and this is what I did for my Mum. The building is quite plain but is all the more interesting because of it as the architecture is not overshadowed. There

We spend our last Christmas (2015) in Toulouse and on the second day we visited this Basilica. This is just 15 mins walk from the metro station Capitol. This place is listed as a Unesco world heritage site and is the largest Romanesque church. The building is make of Red

As a lover of religious architecture, I cannot recommend this location any more highly. Every nook and cranny is filled with religious significance, and no matter how much time you allow, you will run over as you marvel at what you see.
Like most of these places it's well worth a visit to find out the history and background that surrounds it. Worth a visit.

This huge but also simple and complicated at the same time is a must see for anyone visiting Toulouse. It has an extraordinary history dating back to the first bishop of Toulouse and was originally built in the 5th c. A major restoration project commenced in the 19th c. and

The Basilica is really the true gem of Toulouse!!! The largest Romanesque church in Europe is large indeed: its magnificent austere exterior reminds me more of a fortified castle than a church. The interior is equally impressive in its solemn tranquility. Beautiful nave! The
Within walking distance from capitole. Not outstanding like in Paris but worth a visit. Free to get in and really beautiful church

St Sernin is near the center, walking distance from the Capitoule (Mayor's office) Tours last two hours however every minutes of them are forth for. They occur on Sat and Sun only at 10:00 and 15:00. They are free except for the ambulatory and crypt. We were welcomed by a young
It is not outstanding by Paris or Sevile standards but worth a visit. Very few tourists. Free to get in. The frescos and sculptures are excellent.
Beautiful Church full of designs and architectural touches. Every single detail is worked and designed with creativity.
This is an awesome church, which provided a very moving experience. It's very different, both inside and out, from many of the churches in Europe. Loved Toulouse - a good vibe throughout.
Beautiful church.. Wonderful things to see. With taking some time to get to know the history of the Bastille
Beautiful basilica, so much history. Worth to see, especially if you are with a guide from Office du Tourisme, they know their history and their town.
Worth checking out when in Toulouse. I was very impressed by the size of this basilica and its fine example of romanesque style. The interior is very bright which was surprising but cool.
Wonderful building set in its own square - well oval to be precise. but a fantastic monument both inside and out.

The height of the ceiling, the length of the columns, the spacious domes…Everything in the cathedral gives you the sense of the unreachable, and leaves you in a mathematical panic, feeling very tiny. When I went, someone was practicing the organ and I wandered around and lost
The best roman basilique in the center of the old town of Toulouse. Walk through charming small streets and you will arrive to a big square where the basilique is located.

The exterior grounds of the church were incredibly dirty - I couldn't help but wonder if there was an event earlier in the day because of the quantity. I hope so because it was a detractor. The church itself was beautiful and brought back memories of visits to Italy and some

Saint-Sernin is one of the biggest attractions in Toulouse, nt least for organ lovers, who flock to hear Michel Bouvard play the exceptional Cavaillé-Coll. There's a souk-like market there on Sunday mornings, all rather 21st Century, really.

The Saint-Sernin Basilica, considered to be the biggest in the western world, listed by UNESCO as an important stop on the Santiago de Compostela pilgrimage. never fails to surprise by the size and beauty of its nave. This beautiful Romanesque building dates back to the 11th and
An absolutely beautiful and unique church, it's just a shame we didn't get to go in. Well worth going to check it out.

This beautiful 1000 years old Romanesque basilica is an historical, architectual and religious reference point in Toulouse. The original crypt, organ, superb decorations , all are just another occasion for the tired traveller to surround himself with exquisitely maintained
The Huge columns and beautiful stain glass windows offer a very nice light contrast all over the main hall of this church.
One of the most impressive churches I have ever visited especially due to it's size. Whenever friens come to Toulouse this is a "must see"

In you ve got the chance to tour in Toulouse city this is a must be seen architectural monument of the 11th century. Not only the Basilique Saint Cernin is a jewel of the neo christian architecture but it embeds many milestone of the city's history such as the 100's war or the

I agree with a few other reviewers on here, in that I was slightly underwhelmed by the interior of the Basilique Saint-Sernin. I don't know if it's because the outside gave a very promising impression of what's within, or because there are so many other more beautiful churches

The area is beautiful and the building is outstanding thanks to its bricks. They might be red but look pink like in most of Toulouse and this gives Toulouse its name "Ville Rose" (Pink city) and it sure is.

Having seen so many churches, I am a bit "churched" out! So, this review is definitely biased. Because the church is so close to the Capital, you will probably come across it anyway but I think you would have to have a specific interest in church architecture to fully appreciate
Although impressive from the outside, Saint-Sernin is gloomy and claustrophobic, over furnished and not my cup of anything. I couldn't wait to leave.
One our more enjoyable experiences in Toulouse!This is a beautiful basillica ...The architecture inside and out will impress!Definately visit

Saint-Sernin is the largest remaining Romanesque building in Europe, renowned for it's sculpture and architecture. Built mainly of the red brick so endemic to Toulouse, between about 1080 and 1120, with additional construction continuing up to 1860, and some restoration
An interesting church worth visiting. Plenty of information in English. Within walking distance of main square.
I really enjoyed Basilique Saint-Sernin because of the huge amount of detail in the building. It was an extremely peaceful, quiet place to be.
Very pretty church, with rich history. Pay the extra Euro's and see the crypt below. The architecture and artifacts are fascinating.

Nice place but you have to say the outside view of the tower (steeple?) is everything. Adorably lit up at night (as is everything in Toulouse) . Cant put my finger on it but something is disappointing on the inside (eg compared with Santa Maria del Mar in Barcelona)
Worth the visit. Beautiful inside and wonderful location in the city. Pipe organ is wonderful. Great places for coffee and large marche nearby as well
Worth wandering along to visit this church in Toulouse. It is quiet, bright and interesting, take some time out for peace and reflection here.

The history of the place is very exciting. It was built in 1505 as pointed out in the history plaques in the side of the building. It is a good place to visit when you are strolling around in Toulouse.
This church sits to the north end of the town centre so easy to access. Enjoyed looking round. Grand place. 2.5 Euros to access the catacoums but otherwise free
Lovely church with interactive consoles to see the history of the church. I didn't realise how much history was in Toulouse.
The front entrance doesn't suggest the grandeur of the inside, It is remarquable. A little bit like a protestant church in regards of the location of it's choir.

One of the most beautiful cathedrals I've ever visited . Accessible to the audience with large colorful windows , in an atmosphere of harmony. The visitors love to watch the big organ at the one side of the Church.

Saturday morning, there is a little flea market around this church. Walking around it also gives you different perspectives on this large construction, said to be the largest Roman church in Europe (at least still operating as church). Anyway an amazing building with its tower

Very large, old church, easily accessible from Toulouse centre, a must to fit into a walk around the city. Romanesque dating from 11C with some very interesting features, such as the altar (very impressive).
This is an outstanding example of a large Romanesque Church. If this kind of architecture and art appeals to you this is worth making a visit to.

The biggest and most beautiful Romanesque church of the Midi. Just standing in the back, you cannot help but admire the space, the beauty of this site. Visit to the crypt has an entry fee, however, the church is free of charge. Worth the visit.

On our walking tour, we were told about the crypt and encouraged to go back after 2 when it opened. It was very interested to see the treasures of the church there. The church itself was also lovely to look at, and well worth the visit.
What a beautiful place. As the largest remaining Romanesque church in Europe, if not the world, it is a wonderful sight to behold.
A visit to Saint-Sernin is a must. A lot of work has been done in recent years and this well preserved Icon is in excellent condition. Nearby you can visit the MSR museum, just across the Basilica.
Nice church, but that's it. Very simple, not much decoration. Definitely essential. Do not expect the opulence of italian churches

THE unmissable monument of Toulouse- jewel of romanesque architecture. Make sure you walk all the way around the building. From hère walk down the rue du Taur till you come to Toulouse's main square - La place du Capitole Stop for a béer or coffe in The amazing Bibent café

I have visited this fortified church on numerous occ Asians and never cease to be amazed by it. It's fortunes have gone up and down over the centuries from church to stable and back to church again, and is now cared for very well. Absolutely stunning modern stained glass and,
