text.wiki:
The Augustinian Convent of Toulouse was founded in 1286 for members of the Augustinian religious order.  It was first established outside the city walls, near the Matabiau quarter, then, between 1310 and 1341 moved to the corner of rue du Musée and rue des Arts.  In 1790 it ceased to be a convent and today its buildings house the Musée des Augustins.


== History ==


=== The construction of the convent ===
In 1269 a community of Hermits of St. Augustine was founded outside the city of Toulouse, near to the Montolieu quarter. The construction was due to the Chapter of Canons Regular of St. Sernin who undertook to build a convent in exchange for land and rights that newcomers granted them from the donations they had received (Departmental Archives of Haute Garonne, 101 H 638). As frequently happens in the history of religious foundations, this initial location proved inadequate to the needs of the community.
In 1309/1310, the hermits of St. Augustine obtained the Pope's Clement V approval to sell this first building, and purchase the land to build the existing buildings that lie within the walls of the city, in the parish of Saint-Etienne. The canons of Saint-Sernin objected to the transfer, but, in 1326 sold three houses to the hermits for the price of 3500 guilders in exchange of a part of the wax sheets received by the Augustinians for a burial.
Jean Lobres, prime contractor of Toulouse's cathedral participated in the construction of the apse of the church. The layout of the church is typical of the southern Gothic style. The apse has three chapels that open directly onto the large, single nave, there is no transept, and in the upper parts, sections have been cut out.  By 1341 the foundations of the monastery were well established.
The completed church was painted in the style typical of northern Spain during the first half of the fourteenth century and decorated with miniatures produced in the royal court at the time of Philip IVth of France (Philip the Fair). The campanile is built on a square and close to the chorus. Access is via the opening which is now located in the vestry. The construction of the eastern part of monastery began in 1341. Construction of the other three parts of the building were only begun in 1396 by the mason Jean Maurin. Ninety years later, in 1396, the cloister was completed.


=== The fire of 1463 ===
Starting on 7 May 1463 and lasting for nearly two weeks, a fire (started by a careless baker) destroyed much of the city of Toulouse. As was the case at the Carmelite convent, most of the roof collapsed. With the help of the faithful and the church, reconstruction of the roof began in 1495 through the work of masons Martin Pujol and Pierre d'Arroye. The work was quickly completed and the building was rededicated on 30 June 1504.


=== The decline of the convent ===
Up until the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries the convent was home to two hundred monks. But then numbers started to decline; by 1518 there were no more than 140, and the fall continued. In 1649 there were only  60 and in 1680 there were only 31. By the time of the French Revolution only a few remained. In addition, in 1542, the convent was the victim of looting; many books and records were stolen from the Library, along with liturgical objects and valuable furniture. On 14 September 1550 (the feast of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross), lightning struck the bell tower. The upper floors were destroyed, causing extensive damage in the surrounding area. This event marked the beginning of the decline of the monastery. The financial and material difficulties could not be overcome and the bell tower was never reconstructed, instead it was lowered by one floor.
In May 1562, in the aftermath of the revolt of the Huguenots, three Augustinians were flogged in public, apostatized, and married to three Augustinian nuns for having left their convent.  During this time, all the Augustinian nuns (bar one) of Toulouse became part of the Protestant Reformation, and the house was donated to the Jesuits (the Chapel of the Black Penitents).
In a decree of 2 November 1789 the convent became a national asset, and was decommissioned during the suppression of the monastic orders in 1790. Since 27 August 1795 it has housed the Toulouse Museum of Art.

Part closed due to renovation so no access currently to upper flor and art display but still worth a visit. Many archeological exhibits in fine setting, the church is particularly interesting building

We have visited Toulouse many times but we had not visited this museum before. The building itself is beautiful but is currently in the process of having major renovation works. Therefore, when we visited the art galleries were not accessible. Nevertheless, for a reduced
Lovely building, pleasant cloisters with statues. Both roman and medieval figures, helpful staff and a reasonable price. Would be interesting to children and adults

This museum in a former Augustine Abbey, is a wonderful peice of architecture. It's fault if anything is that it tries to do too much, it seems to be dedicated to the ecclesiastical history of the Toulouse area while not libling up the excepts. The two cloisters are lovely

The weather was awful so this was a good place to the visit.The building is massive.The rooms are well laid out and the medieval sculpture display is beautiful .Unfortunately the display of paintings on the first floor is temporarily closed,but the plus side is they have reduced

We were quite excited to visit this gallery as they have a fine collection of French paintings but sadly none of them were on view as that floor is entirely closed until 2019 due to the renovations. So of the 4,000 works held by the museum we saw about 400, and not the ones we

One of the highlights of Toulouse, this is a former monastery, splendid example of Gothic architecture, listed as a historic monument. Nowadays, it is a home to several thousands of museum collections pieces, mainly paintings and sculptures from the likes of Delacroix,
It is one of Toulouse landmarks, right in the center. The architecture is splendid. Permanent expo is interesting. A good place to spent a 2h cultural visit.

We spent just over an hour here. It would have been longer but the first floor housing a collection of paintings was closed for renovations, although there was a temporary makeshift exhibition of artwork in part of the complex which was the church. The museum complex is an

It was a nice visit, however we had 2 small backpacks and they would not let us get in with those, neither leave it in the clock room. We have to walk all the way back to the station, leave the luggage in lockers and come back.

We stop at the museum whenever we are in Toulouse, sometimes more than one times. Why? Great location, close to the Esquirol metro stop; down the avenue from the river and bridge; walking distance from the Capitale; etc. The gardens offer a place to sit and reflect, as well as
Must go to place in Toulouse if you want to know the ancient culture and traditions. Worth exploring

The Augustine monestary is a lovely exampleof southern Gothic architecture.It contains more than 4 000 paintings and sculptures by famous artist like Delacroix,Ingres, and Toulouse-Lautrec Unfortunately I could not load some great photos. You will have to take your own ones.
Yet another great museum, set in a glorious building. Loved the gargoyles and medieval etchings. Loved the lights above the columns. A really lovely setting. Don’t miss this museum.
Most interesting museum with wonderful exhibits. I could have spent half a day there. Very convenient to Place du Capitole.

Let's get down to the nitty gritty first, before I gush. Tickets for this museum cost €6. If you want to get an audio guide it will set you back another €2. Is the audio guide necessary? Well, I visited twice (as I had the Toulouse Pass Tourisme card). My first visit was

Visited this museum and I was very impressed with its collection of paintings and sculpture from the Middle Ages to the early 20th century. There are over 4,000 items in the collection including works from Delacroix, Ingres and Toulouse-Lautrec. In the centre of the museum, I
The reduced admission reflects the fact that the paintings were closed off (2n floor). I have to say the 1st floor exhibits were worth the admission.
A must see with lots of great items. Great courtyard, great art, and OK sculpture also. Definitely worth a visit.

The paintings rooms are closed, so the most important part of the museum is not accessible during this period. The building by itself and the exhibition about the transformation of Toulouse are not, in my opinion, worth the effort.

It is almost worth going in for the building alone -- a beautiful, airy former monastery complete with cloister garden. But the collection, though fairly small, is also a joy, ranging from Roman capitals and Renaissance paintings to stonework from the Middle Ages. The organ is

I was only able to visit for 20 minutes since the museum was closing, but I had a free pass to most Toulouse museums on my 24 hour tourist pass and so visited anyway - I wished I could come back and spend several hours
A one time monastery now a museum with in interesting collection medieval statues and gargoyles. Also a big collection of capitals displayed very effectively.
In about an hour, you can leisurely walk through the museum and enjoy the garden in the center. The cost was 6 euros.
Even though the painting were unavailable on our visit, the use of space for the displays in this former church and convent was brilliant. Especially the capitals with the color coded lighting.

Magnificent location for a museum. The building was originally the Augustinian convent built in 1309. After the French Revolution the Augustines were shown the door and it opened to the public as a museum. It’s been a museum since. It revolves round a courtyard which is now a

Disappointing. Pretty courtyard and some interesting (very old/crumbly) sculptures in the rooms surrounding. However turned out the gallery was closed - the lady at the desk said for the last 2 years?! Not worth €6.

The museum is worth to see. Gargoyles from the Couvent des Cordeliers welcome you from the doorstep. Colored lamps and façade elements, fixed on colored columns allow to see their details. There are also paitings and sculptures inside.
Nice to visit, especially if you are art lover.. very old paintings and lot of history, dont forget that all information is in french.
The building of this museum is very interesting. Particularly fascinating is the cloister and the old sculptures.

It was disappointing that whilst refurbishing they have not taken the trouble to exhibit their more important paintings rather than just making them unavailable. Especially the Élisabeth Vigée-le Brun and Guido Reni which in their publicity. Tsk!
For the art and History lovers, this is a must go in Toulouse. We were in love from the beginning to the end with the visit.

Absolutely beautiful to walk around, with some outstanding installations. Really cool to have such an old building with some really modern artwork in - a nice twist. Beautiful little courtyards here and there too. Recommended!

This museum is so original. It is like a collection of rooms situated around a beautiful square garden. Each room has a different collection of art. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because ALL the staff were moody. I was also told off for using a selfie stick outside in the

I had a few hours before catching my bus so I chose this museum. The collections that were available were interesting. Some of the descriptions were in English and Spanish but many were not. Two of the three main galleries of paintings were closed as was the church. It is a

Beautiful building and great collections of medieval and Renaissance art. I would rate it much higher were it not for the fact that the best galleries of paintings are closed for renovation leaving the visitor with only a roomful of Academic and local painters. Quite

A very good example of a high quality provincial museum. Don't expect the Orsay or Louvre and you won't be disappointed. A nice array of sculpture, paintings, architecture, and when we visited a very interesting modern and installation. Plus it is right next to a good grocery
It's a great museum with a rich collection of sculptures and paintings. There is also an organ with weekly concerts that are a must-see.

It is pleasant to walk in the Musee des Augustins. Personally I was impressed by the architecture more than by the art contained in the Musee, even though there are interesting pieces by Toulouse Lautrec and Rodin. It is certainly worth a visit.

We spent a very good hour visiting this attraction. At €4 for adults it was well worth the money.the buildings are simply stunning and as it was a lovely sunny day the reflection of the sun on the bricks really bought out the colours. Some really interesting exhibits and the
The museum is well maintained, well staffed and extremely pleasant. Entry fee of Eur 5 is minimal and the medieval sculpture is worth viewing whilst winding down and enjoying the serene environment.

Another interesting public building to visit for its high cultural value. Historically the church and its cloister are secluded havens of peaceful ambiance. The colonnaded cloister goes around the grassy central courtyard and gives access to other museum chambers were
This museum is great for a visit on an afternoon. There are lot of exhibits and the garden is nice. There is an entrance fee - 5 € for adults and free for kids.

If, like me it was raining in Toulouse and you wanted something cheap to do (free for students!) then Musée Augustins is for you. It's got a lot of sculptures downstairs then upstairs there's an interesting light exhibition. Up again and there is an extensive collection of art.

Several important pieces by masters, well displayed in the church. Sunlight coming in the high windows enhanced paintings utilizing light for central subjects. In the upstairs gallery, some pieces were mounted too high to see well. Many very nice pieces were of local interest.

Highly recommended museum developed around a exquisite garden. A variety of sculptures, paintings etc from different periods presented in very well preserved manner. Entrance fee very small for what you get to see. Overall very impressed.

The interior courtyard is a beautiful place to enjoy. The fine art collection is well selected. The Jorge Pardo design for the CAPITALE collection is wonderful and intensely colorful. The museum takes about two hours to cover. It is worthwhile to get the audio headset. A

We enjoyed a good couple of hours here. There's a strong religious theme to quite a lot of the exhibits, which won't be everyone's cup of tea, but there are a lot of very interesting things to see, and the building itself is very impressive, including a beautiful courtyard &

The museum is a former monastery, built in the 14th and 15th centuries. This lovely old building provides a wonderful atmosphere in which to display art. Perhaps fittingly for a former monastery, the majority of art on display is of a religious nature. The old church provides

This place Toulouse has the great work of the sculpture and art of the medieval times to contemporary . The display here is a treasure to times and will remain so . The stunning architecture will leave you with a glory of the art and the craftsmanship . The experience of being
one of the best collection of sculpture and paintings from the Middle Ages to the early 20th century, including a unique collection of Romanesque works. A great place to visit!

I've been to a few places in France however for a combination of beautiful architecture, art work: historical and contemporary, atmosphere, history and future for me, for 5€ it had it all! Would definitely visit again if only for the extreme pleasure of the oh so peacefulness of

Great place to visit, will only take 1 to 3 hours to complete, depending on how interested you are in sculpture and medieval art. However, the garden is fantastic and some of the paintings would MOMA or the Louvre
Wonderful old monastery with a beautiful cloister. Decent selection of art with a lot of religious sculpture.

This museum is well located on the Rue de Metz. It is set in an old monastery and the buildings are around a central courtyard garden. The museum has wonderful architecture, inside and out. There are sculptures and paintings and other artifacts. The former church area has
We did only see the museum from the outside which is really a nice place and buildings, if the inside is as nice it is clearly worth a visit.

Easy to access - clean - well maintained - well staffed museum. Worth a visit. A nice way to spend an afternoon in Toulouse. There is even a little courtyard garden - but it could use more of a green thumb!

I went to visit this museum on Saturday 1:00pm and I did have a high expectations. Unfortunately, they have to close it for an hour because they didn't have enough staff. So I went back there. It was kind of average collection of paintings and sculptures.

This was one of the main museums that I tried to fit in to a limited window of time the museum its self consisted of 3 main sections which was the church, museum and art gallery I must warn that if you don't like more dated art and sculptures this isn't the place for you I would
Nice Museum & historic building in central Toulouse. Interesting exhibits and grounds. Free on the 1st Sunday of the month.

We appreciated the setup of the museum with different spacious rooms that are all different so that you don't get bored easily while walking through the museum. The building is really a nice location for this collection.

We enjoyed this museum and its beautiful spaces, with sculptures, paintings and statues. It is a digestible size with good quality pieces. Glad we visited!

This is not your average museum. The work is spread out throughout three separate buildings which at one time housed monks. It was very fun and informative. Loved it and worth a visit.
Wasnt expecting much, but some of the rooms are filled with very good XV century paintings. Some very famous painters are represented here.
There is lots to see here. Nooks and crannies filled with sculpture and paintings donated to the museum from all over make it very worthwhile to spend several hours here. Gardens are a delight, too.
Really enjoyed this centrally located museum, the medieval sculptures were particularly amazing, well worth the trip on their own

A friend and I were lucky enough to be in Toulouse the first Sunday of May and entrance to the museum was free. This museum is small but full of interesting objets d'art arranged in small rooms. Some rooms have only paintings, some only sculptures and others a mixture. I enjoyed

The cloister garden is as beautiful as it is peaceful with benches for you to sit, reflect and enjoy the calm. The museum has several themed areas with gothic sculptures and art work. Finally the church is breath taking. Well worth a visit.

This is a beautiful building and well worth visiting no matter what special exhibitions are on as the central garden, the architecture and the permanent exhibits are all interesting and beautifully presented. Certainly a quiet reflective contemplative gem in the City.

This is a great Museum to visit although I would suggest you allow a full hour to look over it in some detail. As with most former Monasteries it had taken a fair amount of bashing about but has been brought back to life with a wonderful exhibition of sculptures and statues and
We enjoyed seeing a collection of unique and unusual objects, paintings, and sculpture in a centuries-old building.
Lovely experience in this magnificent building. Very helpful staff and a mix of modern and old. Beautiful working garden in the middle of the the grounds, well worth a visit.

Interesting and varied collections in a fabulous setting. I was particularly impressed with how the works were lighted so that they called to you. The temporary exhibition theme was courtyards. They provided a detailed handout in English of the temporary exhibit.

Supposed that it will be just a visit to monastery and inner yard, but haven't expected such a rich collection of picture art (even Delacroix and Toulouse-Lautrec) and column caps from XII century churches, selection of bronze and marble statues. The most peculiar - collection

Lovely and eclectic collections, from 13/14 century gargoyles and medieval wall paintings, to 15th-17th paintings in a chapel to the 17th-20th century painting galleries. English in most sections although full translations are missing.

Architecturally one of Toulouse's most attractive buildings The temporary exhibition (as of March 2017) on the subject of Courtyards in art, was a model of how to take a group of works only a few of which could be called masterpieces and make an interesting show of them:

Visited this museum on a Monday as we had time to spare before heading for airport and nothing much open on a Monday. So glad we did visit as this was one of our highlights. Suggest you use the audio guide to make the most of it.

Well worth a visit if in Toulouse. We spent over two hours there. It is a beautiful and very old building while the are collection has a mixture modern paintings and ancient stone work. Use the audio guide.

This would be a MUST for any visit to Toulouse. The cloisters were wonderful, the art inside a nice overview of mostly French sculptures (marbles) and paintings. There was also a small contemporary show on inside, which was great fun.

Beautiful building, former church of the Augustins Order, which is hosting several art collections inside. We visited the paintings section (quite a rich collection with impressive paintings, I especially liked the ones of Philippe de Champaigne, Delacroix, Toulouse-Lautrec),

the building itself, with the cloister &the staircase, is beautiful; the exhibits (roman capitals from local churches and cloisters that have been destroyed) are amazing, the first floor however, which hosts 19th paintings looks very dated

Art, sculpture and history all in one, very interesting and informative. The architecture is fascinating but there is a lot of walking and steps to climb. Lovely cloisters and quiet spots in the gardens to just sit and take it all in. There was some building and restoration work
Excellent collection of religious sculptures and French and Italian paintings from the 15-17th centuries. Not many people if you visit during weekdays early in the morning. Very pleasant visit.

It's one of the biggest museums in Toulouse! Paintings and Sculpturs, not Modern Art! Not famous for its paintings of renowed painters, but it has a nice selection! They have a temporal expo by Jorge Pardo that is just breathtaking!

It is monastery turned into museum - so you can se beautiful example of gothic architecture, nicely preserved. Inside fantastic exhibitions. Gothic sculpture galleries are absolutely outstanding! That's my favorite part of the museum, but there is so much more to see. Very rich
I ended up spending almost two hours there,just so I can observe and enjoy every part of it. Impressive and lots to see.
This was an unexpected gem. A great expo going on...well worth a visit to get a little history of Toulouse
I really recommend to visit this place for sightseeing. It is really worth seeing with very good paintings and sculptures.

Starting with the cloister, which is quite splendid, this is an important museum for anyone interest in medieval art and architecture. There are lots of Gothic statues, gargoyles, devotional items and, above all, a wonderful group of capitals. These have been arranged by a

This exhibition is a "pot-pourri" of art work . Some great scupture and paintings and also a great collection of "capitols" that have important interest but did not hold mine throughout. Notwithstanding, you should visit is museum.

Museums by their very nature display artifacts of interest. But it is rare to have the display of the artifacts to be as interesting as the items on display. The Musée des Augustins capitalizes on its beautiful historic structure and courtyards to creatively display familiar

I really liked the layout of this museum and found the English audio guide very helpful. If you get tired walking around the museum you can stroll into the nice garden in the center of the complex and relax on the benches there.

I would definitely recommend to go when in Toulouse, also given that there isn't a huge amount of things to visit in the city. I enjoyed visiting it - there was not too much and I mostly focused on the highlights. A couple of hours well spent and besides the building itself it's

Many different periods and themes to choose from and spent sufficient time on a section rather than trying to get around the entire space. It is huge. Easily accessed with many cafes and shops nearby the gallery museum is restful with the surge of Toulouse going on all around.
Super museum, with a lot of history, its not expensive to go in (5 euros) and you can enjoy the garden and all. Good location near to transports (metro Esquirol), take at least 3 hours to be inside.

We fell upon this and we're rewarded with a free visit today. Some very ancient religious sculptures good to view. Quiet little courtyard where you can have a drink and a little break from the heat of the day. Recommend.

This a fantastic museum with plenty of paintings and sculptures to see. We had our 9 year old with us and he also enjoyed it. We spent about an hour here and it was only 10 Euro for 3 of us so great value.

we enjoyed the impressive church, delicate sculpture and this recent exhibition of the 'sculpture romanes' . The way they have been set is fantastic : between ancient and modern, we took many pictures. well worth the £5!

It's a sudden plan and visiting here. So that city center is quite little busy and we went here also on Sunday so there is free access area only available to see inside. So we went and see those pictures and paintings. It's quit interesting. If you visit that some other days
Not the most interesting collection for a big museum like this. There is one hall that's just columns. Hundreds of them...

Really enjoyed out potter around this well laid out museum. There is a lovely courtyard where you can rest and let everything sink in, great deckchairs! The layout of sone if the exhibits is unique and there are a significant number of English details given, something lacking in

Visited it with my wife and three kids for the whole morning. We all lobed it including the kids. The display is beautiful especially the sculptures and the display on top of the columns on the second floor. The cloister is a peacefuk place where someone could spend a whole

Worth the time, not expensive to visit and the 2 euro guide makes all the difference. It has a mix of art, sculpture a large, airy cloister and gardens plus a long row of gargoyles!. Something for everyone.

We started our Bastille Day here at the Musee des Augustins. It has a marvelous collection of architectural sculpture, artistic sculpture and paintings. I particularly enjoyed the Toulous-Lautrec pieces in the painting gallery. The presentation of column capitals in the gallery
The building is huge very well located close to the square of the capitole. Nice if you like history

This is a wonderful collection of exhibits and is beautifully organized. It was true key fascinating especially the lower level which was largely devoted to materials form the Middle Ages. The upper level has a very large collection of paintings- some from world famous artists
Best among the places I visited in Toulouse. The room decorated by Jorge Pardo will stay in memory. A large collection of sculptures and paintings mostly from the region.
this museum is set up in the old Augustin convent Interesting art collection and history of the city

The building is amazing and the exhibitions are fascinating. The garden in the middle of the building is just gorgeous. I was there on the first Sunday of the month and it was free, apparently this is always the case. There are also activities for children if you come with small
This was a really well balanced museum with something for everyone. It is not too big and not too small, perfect to see everything without running through the teens' attention span. Highly recommend.

The museum has plenty of sculptures, lovely cloisters etc to see for 5 euros. The ticket allows you to pop put for lunch and return later to complete your visit. Lots to see and a good way to spend a few hours, especially if wet!

Its great to see all the pieces of art in this museum, however its sad that the light on the paintings are now in a good position, they make reflexes and its dificult see all the details of the paiting. Still they have and amazing garden and the church and the exposition and all
Different things to see - statues, huge rooms with art, old chapel, modern light installation, and courtyard garden. Not a Must See, but reasonable if you have time. Not open on Tuesdays.

Free the first Sunday of every month. Lots of very well exhibited items from ancient sculpture to interesting paintings on the first floor. The building and garden alone are worth a visit, and there was a dramatic performance in the garden the day we visited.
Des Augustins is in the middle of the city centre. This museum is inspiring. There are lots to see from pairings to sculptures and a wonderful garden. A must see when in Toulouse.

First, it costs only 5€ for a normal ticket and free for a student. Second, I was impressed by this big and beautiful building and church. Third, the way the statues and paintings were shown here are very beautiful and impressive. Fourth, highly recommended!!
This is the place in the centre of Toulouse or sculptures and painting. I believe entry is free the first Sunday of every month, coinciding with the traffic-free day.

Very interesting exhibition! Worth visiting! I love the Gothic architecture and Romanesque sculptures from the 12th to 15th Centuries. I've visited also the temporary exhibition hall, very beautiful paintings. Never seen such beautiful paintings in Asia before, therefore I am

Makes for an interesting afternoon exploring the history of the region; we particularly enjoyed the sculptures and the gisants (French, "recumbent") which give you a sense of life as a knight in the middle ages. Do take the guided tour head set, it really helps to get the

The museum has a beautiful collection of gothic sculptures, a well-displayed room of romanesque capitals, some interesting nineteenth century paintings. The gargoyles from the Convent des Cordeliers displayed in the cloisters are remarkable. There was a temporary exhibition

Interesting column exhibition. But the painting collection is extremely crowded and mixed with paintings hanging all along the wall in a rather random order so that it's even quite hard to find the descriptions for certain paintings.

On a wet wintry day, I spent over an hour here: lots of sculptures and gigantic early paintings. I enjoy going to galleries but I am no expert when it comes to art, so I am not in a position to comment on the quality of the works on display. But the building is magnificent.
Great museum in beautiful setting of an old monastery. Its probably not that interesting for young kids though.

My museum time limit has shrunk as I've aged, and now two hours is about the max I can do before my feet start hurting. Well, maybe 3, but definitely not more. The Musee d'Orsay and Louvre in Paris are both so huge that I always leave before I've seen half the art, or else
Wonderful museum in stunning building. Artefacts well laid out. Go there for the beauty of the building as much as the contents.

Lovely building from outside but apart from the sculptures many of which you can see from the street outside there seems to be nothing here. It really COULD be amazing and probably will be one day. But isnt right now.

The museum is amazing - walking round the cloisters with a tree full of sparrows singing in the sunshine! A beautiful building with Gothic architecture - the vaulted ceilings in many of the rooms, the structured tower and the exhibition of sculptures make this a must to visit.

Spent an hour and a half admiring the sculptures and some enormous paintings. Mainly early work with a few cotemporary items. The building is a delight too. English map and guide avail. 5 Euros entry.
Great place to visit, on many levels, disability lifts available. A small fee charged but well worth a visit.
Lovely building but the exhibits were not as inspiring as I had hoped. Gardens were nice and the price at 8euros p.p was not too bad. A pleasant way to while away a hour.

The building itself is very nice. The exhibition with the sculptures maybe interesting for some but wasn't that for me. So if you have some time left during your visit in Toulouse take the time to walk through the building.

This is a really big museum with lots of sculptures and paintings . Very polite staff, nice prices and good information system. The area with the paintings is very stunning even though all the tablets below those were only in French , which was really very difficult for the

We were blown away with the cloisters and garden enclosed. A beautiful working garden right in the centre of the city. The fine art paintings were a joy and the presentation of the ancient stone artifacts with modern lighting was genius. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

An interesting art collection that is presented in a bit of a random manner. Much more information on the works of art should be posted so that visitors could better appreciate what they are seeing. The building itself is worth seeing.

Beautiful artwork by some famous artists is housed in a gorgeous old monastery dating back to the 14th and 15th centuries. The building is set around a central courtyard filled with flowers and vegetables. For a relatively small city in France, this museum contains some

This is a nice venue for a spectacular exhibition of religious sculpture and associated art. I've given it three stars simply because it is not a museum and will not suit people seeking history over art.

Beautiful cloisters around a herb garden enclosed by very different exhibitions on all sides. Wonderful Roman and medieval works with large statuary you can examine at close hand. Not really into 18/19C Romantic stuff but upstairs gallery full of very large bucolic paintings. My

Musee des Augustins was filled with great art and sculptures, but for having so many staff members guarding the place I didn't feel very engaged. I would have like the staff to offer some information on the artwork on display. However it did have some great community links,

All the guide books point to this as a great collection, but I found it underwhelming. At least one major section was closed; the large, old-style galleries of French 18th and 18th century pictures was frankly boring; the staff seem uninterested. Not one I would return to.

Wonderful museum with amazing concept and fantastic exhibits. It is a perfect place to spend several hours walking around rooms galleries and also enjoying the garden. The staff that works there is very helpful and polite. Loved the paintings, loved the gothic statues as well

Small and well organized. The exhibits themselves are very artistically set. Some excellent displays. Definitely worth the 5€ euro entry fee which is good for the whole day. And just around the corner is St. George square where you can find plenty of cafés for a refreshment

Very friendly staff. Beautiful building. Loved roaming around the different halls by ourselves. Quality of the painting and sculputure is very high. Not just their famous Madonna, but also the seventeenth-century prophets in the church impressed us. Loved the hall of
The building itself is old and makes a nice exhibition space. There are a few interesting pieces, but overall the works on display are only of middling value.

text.wiki:
The Church of the Jacobins is a deconsecrated Roman Catholic church located in Toulouse, France. It is a large brick building whose construction started in 1230, and whose architecture influenced the development of the Gothique méridional (Southern French Gothic) style. The relics of Thomas Aquinas are housed there. In the two centuries following the dissolution of the Dominican Order at the time of the French Revolution, it served various different purposes before undergoing major restoration in the 20th century. In the early 21st century, it was partially converted into a museum.


== Name ==
The name Jacobins is the nickname that was given to the Dominican Order in the Middle Ages. Their first convent in Paris was located in the rue Saint-Jacques, (Latin Jacobus), and that name came to be attached to the order itself.


== History ==


=== First church ===
In Languedoc in the early 13th century, Catharism, which the Catholic Church considered a heresy, was strong and growing. In 1215, the future Saint Dominic founded in Toulouse a small community of monastic preachers to combat the heresy, and starting in 1230, the friars began the construction of a small church in which to preach. Built entirely of pink Roman brick, this first building was half as long and half as high as the present church, and very simple in design, in line with the order's vow of poverty. It consisted of a double nave, one side for the friars, and one for the congregation, separated by pillars and screens.


=== Expansion ===

Over the next century, as congregations grew, the church was enlarged and embellished. Between 1245 and 1252, it was extended with the addition of a choir with side chapels. Between 1275 and 1292, the height of the choir was increased, and a vaulted roof constructed. In response to the technical difficulty posed by creating a vaulted roof for the new space, the builders installed one oversized column in the centre from which the ribs radiated outwards in all directions. This feature has come to be known as Le Palmier des Jacobins, the palm tree of the Jacobins.Between 1275 and 1315, the height of the choir was increased, and high windows created above the chapels. The seven-storey bell tower was also added at this time.
Starting in 1325, a new, higher vaulted roof was constructed for the nave in order to bring it into line with the choir. The last component of the century-long expansion of the church was the construction of the chapel of Saint Antonin (separate from the church itself), between 1335 and 1341.


=== Relics ===

Thomas Aquinas, author of the Summa Theologiae and canonised in 1323, was a member of the Dominican order. In 1368 Pope Urban V decreed that his remains be transferred from Italy where he died to the Jacobins, the mother church of the order. When they arrived in 1369, they were placed in a stone reliquary beside the altar. After being moved to Saint Sernin at the time of the Revolution, they were returned to the Jacobins in 1974 when the restoration of the church was complete.


=== Dissolution ===
Following the French Revolution of 1789, the Dominican order was banned, and the friars forced to leave. In 1804 the conventual complex including the church became the property of the city of Toulouse, and in 1810 the emperor Napoleon requisitioned the church and converted it into a barracks. Floors were installed to create upper storeys for dormitories, while stables and an armoury occupied the ground floor. During the period the building served as a barracks, the stained glass windows were destroyed, and the medieval paintings in the choir were painted over with whitewash.


=== Monument and museum ===
Citizens who were appalled at the destruction succeeded in 1861 in convincing the army to move to new barracks. In succeeding years, the building housed an exhibition of Arts and Industries (1865), served as a playground for the pupils of the nearby Lycée Fermat starting in 1872, and as a place to safely store treasures from the museums of Paris during World War I.Several periods of restoration work were undertaken over the course of the 20th century. In 1905 the floors installed by the army were removed; starting in 1923 blocked windows were uncovered and stained glass installed; between 1953 and 1963 the chapels were reconstructed; and between 1965 and 1974 the whitewash covering the medieval murals was removed. Today the building functions as a museum.


== Architecture ==
The round arch at the base of the south side is a vestige of the original romanesque church, while the three solid buttresses correspond to the double-nave layout of the interior which was retained as the church grew. Otherwise the Jacobins is considered a leader in the development of the Gothique méridional (Southern French Gothic) style. One of the most typical characteristics is the fact that it is constructed entirely of brick. Also characteristic is the style of the south wall between the buttresses. Each section consists of a tall Gothic ogival (pointed) arch with a small rose window at the top, and below that a lancet window. The spaces between the buttresses of the nave also show the same ogival arch, in which is set a tall, narrow triple-lancet window. There is hardly any decoration, which is considered to have been a conscious choice aimed at differentiating this church from the highly elaborate Gothic of northern France.The nave also served as a model in the development of Southern French Gothic architecture in presenting a very unified space. The double-nave layout, however, one side for the friars and the other for the congregation, turned out to be inconvenient and was not imitated, whereas the choice of columns to support the Gothic vaulted roof was. Each slender column, only 1.4 metres (4 feet 7 inches) in diameter for a height of 28 metres (92 feet), including 22 metres for the stone shaft (72 feet), supports eight of the ribs of the vaulted ceiling, and the six columns divide the nave into six bays. A seventh column continuing the same line supports the 22 ribs of the vaulted roof of the choir, the famous Palm Tree. This masterpiece is considered a precursor to the complex structures of the later Gothic.

text.wiki:
The Hôtel d'Assézat in Toulouse, France, is a French Renaissance hôtel particulier (urban palace) of the 16th century which houses the Bemberg Foundation, a major art gallery of the city.
The Hôtel d'Assézat differs from the other Renaissance townhouses in Toulouse not only in size and its exceptional ornementation, but also in its pristine condition, a fact which earns it a mention in every overview of French Renaissance. Today, it is home to the Union des sociétés savantes and the Bemberg Foundation. It is one of the first manifestations of French classicism.


== History ==
The Hôtel d'Assézat was likely built by Toulouse architect Nicolas Bachelier for Pierre d'Assézat, an internationally renowned Toulouse woad merchant. The construction of the Hôtel began in 1555 and was not yet completed when Pierre d'Assézat died in 1581. It is an outstanding example of Renaissance palaces architecture of southern France, with an elaborate decoration of the cour d'honneur (courtyard) influenced by Italian Mannerism and by classicism. The use of brick is typical of Toulouse. The Hôtel now belongs to the City of Toulouse and was restored in the 1980s.


== Presentation ==
Pierre Assézat was at the height of his social and professional success when he launched the construction of his mansion close to the Merchant Exchange, of which he had been one of the founders. Nevertheless, he did get caught up in the religious troubles of the time. A Calvinist convert, he was obliged to leave Toulouse after attempting to seize the town along with his fellows capitouls in 1562. He recanted ten years later and returned to his townhouse in Toulouse where he died in 1581.Assézat launched the first phase of construction in 1555–1557. The main L-shaped structure was built along with the staircase pavilion in the corner. The stonemason Jean Castagnié was entrusted with carrying out the masonry works defined by the architect Nicolas Bachelier. The designs of the façades, featuring twin columns which develop regularly over three floors (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian), takes their inspiration from the great classical models such as the Coliseum. The capitals also precisely adhere to classical models, known from engravings. The erudite architecture—its source can also be traced to the treatises of the royal architect Sebastiano Serlio—expresses order and regularity. On the deaths of Castagnié and Bachelier the construction work stopped; it was restarted in 1560 under the direction of Dominique Bachelier, son of Nicolas. He undertook the creation of the loggia and the passageway, which divided up the courtyard, and the street gate. Much polychrome interplay (brick/stone) and various ornaments (cabochons, diamonds, masks) evoke luxury, surprise and abundance, themes peculiar to mannerist architecture.


== Main gate ==
The monumental gate designed by Dominique Bachelier combines power with delicacy. The gateway arch takes a certain rhythm from several projecting stones decorated with small dots. Serlio's Extraordinary Book of Doors contain this type of composition and it was used on several occasions by Toulousain architects (Hôtel de Molinier and Hôtel de Massas). The Doric pilasters that frame the gate display an alternating succession of diamond-shaped stone, which gives the ensemble a precious aspect. In the upper section the Ionic pilasters around the mullioned window are fluted and delicately ornamented. And with the table that surmounts it, the composition imparts a refined sophistication. Thus, Dominique Bachelier was able to offer the owner a complete composition which evoked both power and a delicate erudition.


== The passageway and the consoles ==
In the courtyard, the passageway features arches decorated with diamond-shaped stone. They rest on large scrolled consoles, whose fronts are decorated with grotesque masks of different design. On the side, the rolls of the scrolls engender plant pods and cloves. Each console is borne upon a lion foot standing on a section of pilaster capped underneath with a magnificent rose. These consoles illustrate, by themselves, the manneristic aesthetic on the unusual and the association of opposites, combining mineral, vegetable and animal kingdoms. These refined motifs, heightened through the polychrome interplay and relief of the passageway, were much appreciated by contemporaries and inspired details on other buildings, such as Hôtel de Massas and Laréole Castle.


== Staircase term ==
In the stairwell, on the landing of the first floor, stands the impressive figure of a male term. Half man, half pilaster, his face grimacing and his hands holding a cushion placed on his head to reduce the pain, this term was condemned to support the weight of the console. Although a symbol of knowledge in the sense that it alludes to mythology (Atlas and Hercules), this motif also amuses thanks to an association of opposites, such as the straining muscles and the soft cushion. Cariatid termes and other telamons were much appreciated in Renaissance Toulouse, notable examples can be found on the windows of Hôtel du Vieux-Raisin and on the main gate of Hôtel de Bagis.


== Bemberg Foundation ==

Since 1994, the Hôtel d'Assézat has housed the Bemberg Foundation (Fondation Bemberg), an art gallery which presents to the public one of the major private collections of art in Europe: the personal collection of the wealthy Argentine Georges Bemberg (1915–2011). His foundation was created in collaboration with the City of Toulouse. The large Bemberg collection features paintings, drawings, sculptures, ancient books and furniture. Paintings and drawings are the highlights of the collection, especially 19th and early 20th century French paintings (with impressionism, Nabis, post-impressionism and fauvism) and Venetian paintings of the 16th and 18th centuries.
The painting and drawing collection includes an impressive set of 30 paintings  by Pierre Bonnard and 18th century Venetian paintings by Canaletto, Francesco Guardi, Pietro Longhi, Rosalba Carriera, Giovanni Paolo Pannini, Tiepolo. 18th century French painting is represented by François Boucher, Nicolas Lancret, Elisabeth Vigée-Lebrun and Hubert Robert.
From the Flemish and Netherlandish schools of painting are artworks by the studio of Rogier van der Weyden, Lucas Cranach, Gerard David, Adriaen Isenbrandt, Joachim Patinir, Pieter Brueghel the Younger, Frans Pourbus the Elder. For the 17th century paintings are displayed by Antoon Van Dyck, Pieter de Hooch, Nicolaes Maes, Jan Van Goyen, Philips Wouwerman, Isaac van Ostade.
Italian Renaissance painting is centered on Venice with paintings by Paris Bordone, Jacopo Bassano, Titian, Paul Veronese and Tintoretto while for the 17th century there are works by Pietro Paolini, Giovanni Battista Carlone, Evaristo Baschenis, Mattia Preti.
French Renaissance and 17th century painting are represented with Jean Clouet, François Clouet, Nicolas Tournier while the Foundation bought in 2018 a canvas by Spanish painter Francisco de Zurbarán.
French painting from the second half of the 19th century is well represented with paintings by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Eugène Boudin, Claude Monet, Henri Fantin-Latour, Edgar Degas, Édouard Vuillard, Odilon Redon, Paul Sérusier, Paul Gauguin, Louis Valtat, Alfred Sisley, Camille Pissarro, Gustave Caillebotte, Berthe Morisot, Paul Signac and Paul Cézanne.
20th century French art is represented by Georges Rouault, André Derain, Henri Matisse, Raoul Dufy, Albert Marquet, Maurice de Vlaminck, Kees van Dongen, Pablo Picasso, Georges Braque, Othon Friesz, Amedeo Modigliani and Maurice Utrillo.

Marcel Sendrail, Pierre de Gorsse, Robert Mesuret, L'Hôtel d'Assézat, Édouard Privat éditeur, Toulouse, 1961

text.wiki:
The Pont Neuf, French for "New Bridge" (a.k.a. Pont de Pierre and Grand Pont), is a 16th-century bridge in Toulouse, in the South of France.


== Construction ==
Original planning for the bridge started in 1542 by the assembly of a committee of master masons and carpenters.  Construction started on the foundations in 1544; the first arch was started in 1614.  The bridge was finished in 1632, and was inaugurated on 19 October 1659.
The bridge is not symmetrical; the longest arch is the third from the right-hand bank.  The openings through the piers were originally supposed to represent the face and mane of a lion.  A triumphal archway added in 1686 constricted traffic and was removed in 1860.It is 220m long, and has 7 arches.

great view it has. its lovely to walk along. its fresh and soothing. the view is the keystone for this place.

The piers and arches and lion shaped holes were quite dramatic otherwise nothing special. You would not come to Toulouse or go out of your way to see this bridge but there is a very good chance that you will see it if you come down to the river and the place de la Daurade

from the pont neuf continue down to the river side and up for boat trip on the river.a relaxed differnt view over the city of Toulouse

What a wonderful structure. It is easy to see how clever the designers were in allowing for the huge variations in water volumes which come down this river. As usual pont neuf is the oldest bridge.

Bring your sandwiches, cokes and spend the afternoon admiring this beautiful structure next to teh water, lots of people coming and going but still a relaxing place to spend the day in this full of students city, we loved it.
