The medieval castle is so beautiful. I spend 2 hours walking around and take a lot of photos.

The city was Majestic! It's like went out straight from a fairytale.. But be very careful if you go here.. There A LOT of PICKPOCKET. They are very professional that you won't notice. But beside that, the view and the food was fantastic. The price a bit pricey though but it's worth it :)
Best medieval castle I have ever seen. If you love history, architecture or just like pretty small towns... this is the right place. I loved it!

I’m a total nerd for castles and medieval cities and Carcassonne was pretty much the picture perfect place to visit. Its conveniently connected by train to major cities, and the old city is easily walkable for anyone who doesn’t mind a bit …

It is so beautiful. We took a quick walk early in the morning because we didn't really have time but we were still amazed. I highly suggest taking your time in this wonderful city and visiting the castle (which we didn't get the chance).

To be completely honest, we were underwhelmed by the whole thing. The castle is best viewed from the outside, not really a point to pay to go inside as nothing is as it was, you just walk around through it and your done, maybe ten minutes …
A must visit, doesn't disappoint.

Pretty castle which is a tourist magnet. It is crowded with bus loads of tourists. You have been alerted!

The views from the hilltop are beautiful with the town of Carcassonne below.
Visit the town centre. It is a bustling attractive centre with myriad of cobbled alleys with shops, bars & restaurants.
Nice place to visit, food and shops

Fantastic. It's the only walled city that was never conquered and it's reconstructed to the detail. It's been an important place since Roman occupation and the visit is great: ramparts, the views, the castle, the documentary on the history …

An amazing complex. Unfortunately dogs aren't allowed in the castle itself so we can't say anything about that, but the citie is well worth looking round. There were very few shops open as we were there in early February but I think that improved the experience.

Great intetesting place to visit for a night or two.  The walled city is very nice along with the castle.  Great little boutiques and nice bar and restaurants scattered about.  Parking is free at weekends which is a bonus.

I now have a new found interest for ancient castles after visiting this place. Walking around the castle I realized that it has a unique vibe, sometimes i felt like it was a piece from my imaginations, childhood fantasies of castles coming …

Paid a visit at the end of feb. Not many tourist so it was very easy to get around. The weather was warm at 18 degree so it was a great time to visit. The cite is a wonderful place to visit and plenty of history here as well as a modern …
Great to explore this excellent restoration. It gives a good insight into the daily life of the citizens of the time and to walk around the ramparts.

Founded during the Gallo-Roman period, the citadel derives its reputation from its 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) long double surrounding walls interspersed by 52 towers. The town has about 2,500 years of history and has been occupied in different ages by Romans, Visigoths, and Crusaders

This is a very cute and nice little old town. Lots of history and nice ice cream. Little boutique stores on every corner with quirky and handmade goods everywhere. If you are in the area definetly worth a visit.

As long as you like medieval Cités, you'll love it.

The only but I would find to it is the amount of shops, they bring absolutely nothing to the table.
Visit the fortress, walk along the walls, and have so something to eat in the streets. Well worth the visit.
well maintained. little small and not much information available. lots of souvinier shops. must have the cassoulet. duck with beans. really hearty & yummy.

Incredible, detailed and complex example of 1300s fortress.   Be prepared to walk and explore.  Inner castle was worth touring - audio guide was good.  Spent an afternoon walking between the two sets of walls and walking and exploring the old city.  Spent the next morning touring the inner castle/fortress.

It's well-worth a stop in Carcassonne to see the old walled city.  I first visited it in 1974 when I was an foreign exchange student at the University of Montpellier. I've been back several times and always am amazed how one is transported back in time 500 years.
A must visit place for any one who is interested in thirteenth century European history.
Well worth a visit. It's like stepping back in time. Free entry and then just walk around. There's quite a few shops and cafes to choose from once inside the walls

Outstanding medieval city! The city walls and the castle are amazingly well preserved. 
There are good restaurants inside the citadel serving traditional and innovative cuisine. No supermarkets in there though, if you are planning to go for a picnic in the surroundings you better come with all basket full.

Great medieval town and castle/chateau. Never seen a medieval citadel still in use so it was lovely to see a vibrant and still looked after historical place. Plus the cite de carcassonne has days of free entry sooo what reason is there not to go and learn about the history and even enjoy a meal out.

Fantastic experience.  We decided to make a short break here in route to Toulouse with our dog and managed to spend several hours here.  Amazing castle from the outside and inside there are many restaurants and gift shops.  Prices to suit …
Lovely medieval town well worth a visit, stay in the city walls in one of the two hotels if you can

This is the definitive example of a fortified medieval city. For most people, this is what you envision when you think of castles. Well maintained and well displayed museum takes you through the history of the place. Great shopping, …
This is a historical village rich in beautiful places ! It worth a half a day visit.
Reasonable price for entrance thoroughly enjoyed the walled city and the ramparts full of history #Amazing

This place is amazing. We have been there as kids and now we returned with our kids and it is still as enchanting as it was before for us and for them. 

There were some people in costumes walking around the city (paid pictures probably) …
We just love Carcassonne, but especially during off-season. Great visits and an awesome place to dream about ancient times!

Amazing city - well worth a visit. Walk round the walls if you can, as it's free to access the space between the inner and outer walls (the "lice"). Staying there overnight is a good idea, as the crowds are thinner morning and evening.

It's a cool place but very touristy and geared towards tourists with many shops within the walls.  Great if that's your thing but we like to visit historic sights sans commercialism.  We can buy T-shirts and toy crossbows in town.

Stepping back in time. Walking in the tracks of men in old days. Great experience! 
Set aside a day to walk the streets, tour the many buildings, church and wall. Various restaurants are located within the walled city the offer a wide variety of cuisines.
An incredibly restored medieval city! The castle and ramparts are a must see.

Seen a few walled cities but this one is pretty impressive. In excellent condition. Information available in English. 
Worth the €9 to visit the Chateau and walk around the ramparts

Excellent place for tourists. Well worth coming to see the castle city and the city outside. It takes a while to get to know the streets inside the castle walls. Done nice shops. Quite a few restaurants. Most places have English and Spanish translations.

The name is legendary and the Cathar history of the old town and chateau live up to it.  If you're one who tries to read and absorb everything, allow at least 3 hours for the chateau and museum, before breaking off for lunch. Then go back over the draw bridge to tackle the castle walls. Carcassonne merits a full day. Enjoy :)

A great hotel in a great location. Being inside the old city walls was a wonderful experience. The hotel is everything you can hope for. Get there early to experience the old town after all the day trippers have left. Also, the hotel restaurant is a Michelin starred restaurant, so get reservations.

Amazing place. Very busy but not overly. Free to wander around but castle is a 9€ entrance fee. Worth it if you like exploring castles. Plenty of places to eat. We ate in the square where there is a good atmosphere

A must see if you're anywhere in the South of France. Make the effort to get there. I thought it was very beautiful in the early to late evening. That's not taking anything easy from a day visit. Also, the laser show from  the closest bridge was fantastic. Fabulous world heritage building.

A must see! If you like the medieval era, you must visit this place. The castle and ramparts is a great visit to do. Definately not a tourist trap.

Lots of good restaurants inside the walls too. Just avoid most of shops though.
It was a bit touristy but really fun to visit and stay there

Very impressive,  very touristy and  worth a visit if you like shopping within the castle grounds. Lots of people even for out of season. Lots of parking lots around the castle. Free to go in the gate, but you must pay to see inside the museum part.

Just spectacular.Old and historic and oozes charm as does much of France. Loved the narrow cobbles streets and the shopping.Always a bit pricey but too charming to miss and a memorable shopping experience.

Its rich history is what makes it most famous medieval walled city and an important site to visit for those who are passionate about historical places. 

Carcassonne is so well preserved that when you find yourself standing before its …
magnifique je is a la compote of the same color as a la and jenny and jenny and the other one is a great way to go to Spain and
Spectacular and incredible in good status middle age ciutadelle! Incredible romantic in sunset time!
beautiful city but now unfortunately over run by tourists

Beautiful, go ! Stay at a room inside the walls for best experience, auberge de Lices is most amazing and has 2 rooms too. Anytime of year is awesome. We parked at last place before the walled city overnight.. It cost 25 EUR which sadly was half the cost of the room! Rip.. But lovely.

Fantastic place .. despite the August crowds. It's easy enough to find less crowded streets and there are amazing views to photograph everywhere. Narrow streets filled with restaurants and cafes .. Quite spectacular.

Thoroughly enjoyed this beautiful city.  Some of the exhibits are not quite as old as one may think but worth a visit. We explored on bikes with ease. V accessible off the motorway. Had pizza in town which was lush.

We had a great day out today! Parking was easy, and free, and only a 15 minute walk to the city itself. We paid €9 per adult to visit the chateau and this included re-entry until 6pm the same day. The €9 also allowed us to visit the …

I've wanted to visit Carcassone for a long time and I'm so glad I finally did! Stunning views, beautiful streets and plenty of cafes. I was travelling alone and found everyone very helpful and friendly.
this place is cool, lots of history. the audio guide is cool. i recommend it!
Impressive medieval castle and historical site. Not all areas are accessible. Plenty of small stores, restaurants and artisans. Highly recommended!
Great view from the castle. Loved the trip there

It was a wonderful experience and people were very friendly, many shops, and the food was great. Met several other people at lunch from Scotland and Denmark and had great discussions. Since the area is sloped for drainage and streets of …

Magical European town!  What a cute place!  We spent half a day walking around, shopping, eating, taking pictures.  We went in the summer and everything was perfect.  Everything is really well maintained.  There’s easy parking right outside of the city walls.

Ok the day we went, it was free to get in! The walk around the perimeter wall was stunning. The wind was strong, but made it fun. Lots of steep spiral stairs enhanced the castle feel (but be warned if with hard of walking people, it was …
Beautiful medieval fortress if you visit it off season and at night (when here are no crowds of tourists)
Beautiful place. Perfect for any castle lover.
Charming and an absolutely delightful way to spend a day exploring!!
Great views,great vibes. Has to be one of my favourite places in France. If you find yourself in the area go visit, it is well worth it.
many shops and restaurants, breathtaking views. castle unfortunately not seen from the inside.
An amazing place steeped in history. Easy to find. Easy to park. A great day out for all the family with plenty to see and do. Amazing.

Amazing place to travel to medieval times. Very well preserved, beautiful views to the city and brutal vibes. La cité is one of those places that you have to visit at least once in your lifetime. Very touristy, of course but not overwhelming
It is probably the most beautiful castle in the world!! A lot of people - that's true, but it's one of those "MUST SEE"!!!!
Nice place, some part of GOT shooting was done here

Lovely place to visit with a large selection of restaurants to choose from. There are endless amounts of shops to look around a buy a variety of things, you could easily spend a long afternoon here walking around the grounds and soaking up …
Great location to visit. Very old and well kept to this day. Nice restaurants and great Roman style buildings.

Great example of a well preserved medieval city if a tad Disney for my taste.
Our group of four spent 4 nights staying just outside the city walls and we visited many times for food, drink, shows and shopping.
3 stars is a tad harsh for …

Carcassonne is a beautiful, stunning walled city. There is loads of history here and you can walk all around the wall. Inside you can only imagine what it was like hundreds of years ago. We went into the church which is amazing...when three …

It's nice to see such a large and significant medieval style fortress. It would be amazing if the site was actually originally medieval. However, as it is merely a reconstruction in many places it seems to clean and too refined, more similar to Disneyland than a medieval fort.
A Must see. The more impressive middle âge castle in the World. Also with a lot of Charming restaurants
Interesting place to get dressed up and roam around the medieval town and take photos
Stunning buildings and views but very very commercialised and crowded even in mid winter.

A great historic monument given over to commercial tat. I guess that's the price you pay for free general access, although there are parts which you do have to pay to access. The fortress at Blaye does it better.

If you are a fan of medieval castles, I highly recommend a visit! I love how many of the details and material are preserved and there is a village within that is alive! Just that it’s mostly souvenirs shops and restaurants now but still …

Authentic family friendly castle experience jam packed with history and souvenir shops and eateries. Four stars because I couldn't buy the board game "Carcassonne" in any of the shops. Magnificent view from the outer ramparts. Walk up from the city for an authentic experience and free parking.

A fortress over looking the valley of Carcassonne. Still alive with shops, cafes and restaurants. A lovely place to visit and take in the atmosphere within ancient walls. Good for history and architecture.

Just a wonderful experience, just make sure you visit our of high season. Our host said it can be quite 'cramped' otherwise. It is full of all the usual tat but has plenty to see and a host of affordable places to eat.

I'm basically from India, where there are amazing historical monuments and I really enjoy seeing such places. I really loved the view from the Caste it's just something you can't explain. I have shared pics from the watch towers. The reason …
Carcassonne is a must visit for anyone who loves medieval and french castles
Stunning medieval city. Pity that the french managed to turn it into a shopping mall
What a fantastic place full of independent shops and friendly restaurants who are readily aware of the different tourists that visit.  A great experience.
Stunningly beautiful and steeped in history! Restaurants serving wonderful food to tantalize every palate and pocket. A not to be missed location.

Massive medieval castle in great condition. Looks like a storybook castle. Inside is a town with windy streets. Although some of the stores are selling cheap touristy stuff, most of the stores had interesting goods. I came to Carcassonne to …

What a wonderful place .Arrived at 10.am parking easy at this time by 12 noon not so easy.
Had a good walk around took alot of photos really enjoyed it.
Quiet until 12.30 then manic far to busy for me.
Would recommend will return again..A great time was had by all.
Awesome place. Try the cassule with a glass of red in any of the restaurants. Enjoy the scenery

Amazing medieval city. So complete, I've never seen anywhere like it. The first sight of the city is a sight you won't forget. Lovely eateries in the square. The place looks like a film set. Olli be back.
Beautiful. Really recommended. I look forward to my next visit from the UK
A wonderfully intact medieval city. One of the few places you can reside in and find good selection of restaurants. Transports you back in time with its architecture and cuisine.
Beautiful castle, with lots of history. Great wee shops to stroll around. Visit is a must do in Carcassonne
An amazing medieval city. Lots of amazing views, lovely streets, and plenty of places to explore. A gorgeous place to visit.

An amazing place to visit. A UNESCO world heritage site. Three million visitors every year and it's no wonder. I really don't know how they managed to build such a large castle many hundreds of years ago.

A nice place overall but it is very big and you need time a lot of time to experience all of it but there are stores in the inside of the castle where you can eat or buy souvenirs. There are guided and self tours too.

We read in a guide book that the castle inspired Walt Disney's Sleeping Beauty castle. We were inspired also. Impressive buildings and fortifications. Little shops line narrow streets filled with the full range of wares from toys to fine …

Incredible medieval town. It's almost like a film set. Give the walled city 30 mins and I'm certain you could film Robin Hood. Many restaurants and bars to relax in. If you ever wonder about visiting, don't hesitate. Go.
Great place to visit, very beautiful.

Lovely old medieval city. Great walk around the walls and then through the old streets. Mainly restaurants and gift shops - other than that, we didn't think there was much else there. Glad we have seen it but not sure we will rush back .
Fabulous. Good restaurants, bars and shops in an idyllic fairytale location
Beautiful walled city - Christmas lights were lovely.

Great family visit, kids loved the guided tour. The guide was dressed in medieval clothes. The chevalier spectacle was good too.  Definitely a sight to see. Watch out though, it's an expensive day out. The car park isn't cheap.
A lovely place to visit. Some fantastic restaurant's (see my other review) and a chilled walk round steeped in history

A city ... time travel !!! Walking on the cobbled streets ... you hear the hooves of the knights' horses ... the knocks that make the swords in the battles and the voices of the people who run to avoid the stones from the catapults !!!! Just a wonderful attraction !!!
Great for a weekend break with beautiful scenery, nature, historical buildings and lovely places to eat
Amazing. Worth the visit and spend a few hours wandering around the Citadel and the castle

Our guide was easy to understand and very informative on the history and life of the city. She dispelled rumors or incorrect ideas. She tailored all to our age group. I loved walking the medieval streets . Would have liked to walked above the castle but age and mobility prevented that. It was an enjoyable day stepping back in history.
Fantastic medieval walled city. Plenty to see without actually paying to walk the ramparts. Food in the foodie bit in the middle was surprisingly good. Very enjoyable afternoon.

Brilliant day out. If you know the history of the Cathars then this region is very important and interesting. The castle is great. Very busy in June - August. Good today. Had to stop myself buying some boutique goodies.

This has to be amongst the finest walled city anywhere. Beautifully restored, on Roman foundations, the castle itself within also worth a visit, the town itself possibly a little over commercialised, but there is enough to see and do besides that. The walking tour is great, book at the visitors  centre.
If you want to feel like a round table knight go there
Although much of the city was rebuilt in the nineteenth century, it's still an amazing medieval experience. The buildings, shops, restaurants etc. are wonderful. Very family friendly.

Although terribly touristic the fact that it has been restored so well makes a visit almost mandatory. To eat try the small garden restaurant next to the inner keep. In July and August there is a jousting pageant which was great fun.

Visited Carcassonne as we drove through Europe in a £2000 long wheel-base car. (Long story.) Carcassonne is a well preserved and historic. Maybe because it was a hot day, I didn’t really enjoy it that much. It is only really for tourists, …
Just the most wonderful walled city I know. Great central Chateau, side streets to explore, the stained glass windows in the church of St. Gratien and some excellent restaurants
Great weekend with kids: middel age fair and shows, torches parade at night and many more activities for kids and families
Really impressive medieval fortress city full of tourist shops and restaurants. Well worth a visit.

It's a great place to visit, but it's very crowded. Only a few boutiques worth visiting,  otherwise restaurants and same souvenirs everywhere you look. It is a popular place, especially during the month of August.

The entire castle has been made over for the tourists. That said it has been achieved tastefully
There are lots of things to both see and do.
Well worth the visit if you are in the neighbourhood
Well worth visiting, superb views and castle walls. Lovely atmosphere, cafés on the pavement and lovely shops

Beautiful and old. I suggest going in June or earlier when it is less busy. There are beautiful views over the city, gorgeous wall walks and cute little boutique shops. I would suggest also taking 2 days to see la cité and on the second day …
I love this castle and will definitely come back again.

A must see! You can park in the city center and walk 10 to the Cité. If you like the medieval era, you must visit this place and make a tour on his walls. Inside are a lot of shops and restaurants but be careful what you choose because some of them may be expensive and I think it’s a better idea to eat in the city center.
Only the French can turn such a well preserved medieval city into a shopping mall. Could be so much better.

Really enjoyed the old fortress, fascinating history and very impressive structure. Lots of small shops and a huge selection of great places to eat. There are tours available but we chose to use the helpful signage around the castle and …

Just amazing. I've wanted to visit for years, and it exceeded my expectations. Gorgeous walls, lovely medieval lanes, some surprisingly good restaurants in what should be a tourist trap. The castle tour and audioguide are particularly great - we spent three hours there. The most beautiful place we visited in four weeks in France.
This place this lots of fun events that you could to
Best castle I have ever visited. Recommended
Simply unbelievable. We drove the whole way across France to see it, and its was worth it! Also, it is free!!!
Good place you can have a wonderful time
Nothing like it, well-preserved, medieval walled city with photo opportunities at every turn. Don't miss it
Bety beautiful place. It was totally worthy visiting it.
Town close to Spain but totally French feeling over there. Interesting place to visit on the coast. Touristic :)

An interesting and historic city that's well preserved. It is, of course, over run with tourists and full of shops and restaurants that are tourist traps, but there are also some good places. Try and get there early.
Stunning architecture but a total tourist trap experience. Restaurants offer poor quality with little variation of dishes. Duck, duck, duck or pizza 😨
Very nice place to visit for a couple of days
What an amazing place. Well worth a visit and enough to do for a couple if days between the historic city and the lower city
Nice place if you love history. From Gallo Roman to 19th century , the city retrace the history of this city behind those massive walls. Food is also great with the local cassoulet

Wow! Incredible! What a city!
Be aware that it can be very busy with all the tourists!
Would recommend!

This is a fantastic place to visit with lots of things for both young and old. Visit the castle or the inquisition museum and spend time walking through the streets filled with nick-nak shops. There are plenty of places to eat and so you will be spoilt for choice.
Excellent for a long weekend and a super base for getting about the area. Convenient small airport.
Out of the way, incredible sight. Walk the city walls by day and you have great views of surrounding countryside. Some great cassoulet can be found here. Vineyards nearby to tour and taste.
Very beautiful place for one day trip.
So picturesque. So full of Tourists. The locals are blase with customer service which is typically French. But it doesn't negate the beauty of this place.
Great guide, great history!
Medival city, worth the visit
Very nice tourist attraction.
A fantastic and beautiful place where you can travel to the medieval era. I recommend visit the inside of the citadel and see all the sites inside the castle. Really amazing!.
Must have been a hell of a sight back in the day. Nowadays inside the walls is pretty touristic. The inner fortress is a museum which tries to revive the past. Nice views.
Beautiful walled old city. Many shops and restaurants available. There is a cost to tour the castle inside the walled city.
Amazing place just love to walk the walls & streets sit and eat , drink wine mint place
Loved the old town - will definitely visit again - had the best cassoulet ever there
Great view especially in the evening. There are quite a few restaurants in the cite.
We had a good visit but there was an unexpected strike so we couldn't tour the castle instead , very disappointing.
Well worth doing the tour of the castle and the ramparts. A lot of steep and uneven paths can catch you out so not for everyone.
A must see and stay if possible when in the south of France.  Step back in time and enjoy shopping, food, and wine within the ancient walls.
Although quite crowded as one would expect in summer, it is fortunately still possible to walk around freely and enjoy the feel of this great citadel. It is no wonder this is world heritage.
Best to go early in the day to find parking and the streets are a little quieter. Amazing views and the old town shops are really interesting.
Try the escargot in one of the restaurants. Delicious. Amazing view and there are audios you can listen to to learn about the place.

Just stunning! So well preserved...
I sure the walls plenty of small cozy restaurants and souvenir shops with "quality" souvenirs.
The story of the restoration, as well as the medieval feel of the town inside, is great.  Take time to admire from the Pont Vieux.  Spend all day and more.
Very nice and interesting historical sites to discover. Lovely place to spend a long weekend.

The castle is a must. Just like a mini town with the castle walls. Lovely town square. Be aware of opening times for shops museums etc . Not many open on a Sunday. Lovely original cafes. Menu very French not one for the spice lovers

Awesome. City is free to access with lots of eateries and shops. Found many artisan shops exceptionally good value even with the dire £/€ rate. Chateau well worth a visit. Thought about cycling there from Camping de la City but was thankful …

What a place. Never really knew much about the city or the story behind the castle, but so glad I came to see it first hand. Really cute village outside of the town attached to the castle, with tonnes of charm. Was a little tricky figuring out the timings etc as many of the restaurants were closed (Tuesday afternoon around 4pm)
The citadel is very picturesque, but a bit touristy.  Lots of souvenir shops, but also many outdoor restaurants.  Can get very crowded during peak season.

We came in a road trip as family and we decided to visit Carcassonne. The town itself is very simple and cute, so you don't get lost, but the castle is magnificent. It actually made me think of a fairy tail 👌🏾
Fascinating, so many nooks and crannies to explore.

Considering most of France is shut on Sundays it's good to come to a place where there's a bit of a buzz! Yes, it has some tourist tack but there's a lot more that's interesting. Wonderful views, interesting walks and come at the right time …
Great for a weekend away or day trip if you are in the surrounding area
Very good old City to visit
Unique medieval town. Climb the walls, see the town from the old bridge. Cathedral has beautiful coloured glass art.

Unavoidably we went on a Sunday in August and the place was crawling with Japanese and other tourists and hideously hot. We had brunch in a little cafe which took far too long to muster up our order, despite there being few other guests. The buildings and battlements are impressive enough though.

What an absolutely amazing place. If you don't visit this beautiful world heritage site then you really will have missed something special. The inquisition & torture museums were a favourite of the children's. 5 hours spent there felt like 5 minutes & not a single moan from a child.
Just stunning.  Takes your breath away.

Historic and beautiful views. Would be difficult to visit if u are in a wheelchair or need a walking stick because of the hilly ,narrow,cobbled streets. The battlements would be impossible ,with steep stairways but if u are able the cite is well worth the visit
Beautiful Castle have stayed here before. Back again to take in more of the historical value and sites. Recommend for anybody traveling in the south of France. Just below to toulouse.
Tourist trap. Nice but only souvenir shops. Food in restaurants is good. Lots of historical sites.

On a quiet bright sunny Monday who couldn't love this wonderful place.  All the trappings of the tourist trade but I wasn't biting!  Still has all the charm that I was looking for.   I was content just walking the streets and soaking up both the atmosphere and the sunshine.
Great place to visit very large allow good couple hours
Amazing architecture and views. Well maintained.

€8 to enter citadel and you can either have audio guide or leaflet. You walk for MILES so take comfy shoes and there are a lot of steps. Interesting video at start to explain history. No staff anywhere on tour so if you want anything it'll have to wait! Also no cafe inside just a drinks machine
The cite is interesting,  but it feels too much like a tourist trap, disney-like.

Beautiful historic walled city overlooking the more modern commercial part. You do get a feeling of what a medieval town was like. A short walk down from the old city is another old street where there are a few bars, restaurants and cafes. …

What can I say about the City of Carcassonne, firstly the City is actually the fort itself, not the city across the bridge. Once you enter inside the fortress gates across the drawbridge you enter an entirely new place. Cobbled streets and …
Lovely day out. Lots of little side streets and gift shops. The tour is great but I should have got ear phones to get a full history.
Beautiful place. A lot of stores, restaurants and fun places inside this medieval city. A + if you like history.
Very nice and romantic city to spend the weekend. Super hotels inside the medieval city. Excellent restaurants.
Very crowded but very fun location for kids (if they love knights and castles). Full of history for the adults

This is such a well preserved citadel, it really is a must visit.  Wandering around inside feels like you have been transported back in time, especially it is a 'working place' just like.it would have been way back in the day.   There are awesome little shops and a lot of choice for restaurants too. Great souvenir shops as well.
Avsutely stunning. Marvellous historic city with Wall to wall tatt shops and plenty of restaurants. And there's the history and culture stuff tae.

A beautiful place to spend a day. It is free entry for students under 26. And 9 Euros for others. It's at walkable distance from train station. Laid back City and a big fort. If you reach early you can enjoy the place more
Beautiful place lots to see, wished we could stay longer.

One of the few walled medieval cities in the world that fully retains it's historical buildings and is in almost complete condition. If you are interested in medieval buildings and architecture you can't miss Carcassonne. It has to be on everyone's list to visit at least once.
Absolutely stunning. A must see during your trip to southern France.
Definitely worth a visit. A magnificent French castle and walled city. A little touristy in spots but if you make the effort you'll have a good visit
It's a great tourist attraction, a little walk up but the place can keep you plenty busy. Lots of shops and oddities.
Fantastic place of historical significance. The light show is a must... A truly spectacular show.

Amazingly fortified city. The view from the walls and the fort is great. There are many small and curved streets with interesting shops, nice caffes and restaurnts. The cathedral is pretty. There is a knight show at 3pm and 4:15pm, which is also nice.

I enjoyed most of my visit, cassoulet for lunch was yummy. All the commercial outlets ruined parts for me. I did like wandering around the place just absorbing the history. We went early so we're not surrounded by crowds for the first couple hours. I can't imagine what it will be like next month.
If you don't want to pay to go inside of the Castle, don't worry! Because the "Ciudadela" is very nice and free 💃

So much to see and so much history! Beautiful day for a walk - not too many people - great food and great ice cream! Love the history!

This was a wonderful place to go and walk around. Just amazing to see all the history and the very old buildings. Lots of sight seeing to be done - well worth the trip.

What a place so impressed the tour of the citadel was fantastic so much history very well preserved wonderful experience

Must see attraction as in this area which has plenty to offer. The castle tour was very interesting and worth the admission price and the shopping, restaurants etc are plentiful and varied. Beautiful place

Myself and my partner visited Carcassonne and really enjoyed the visit. It was quite quiet in the town but enough going on in the old town and plenty of restaurants open. Highly recommend a visit to Carcassonne if visiting the South West of France.

Medieval city is a nice place to visit any time of the year lots of places to eat and lots of tourist shops. Don't forget Carcassone town is not far and is lovely.

Visited out of season but still bristling with visitors. Would imagine it to be very busy during the height of summer
Beautiful medieval city, with no tourist rush at all. There are sweetshops and restaurants inside. You can walk in the castlewall for 9 euro.

Pinch through the shops, bars and restaurants, and you will see a 2000 year old story from the time of the Romans to the present. The old walls and buildings are like a book, with many stone pages each telling its own architectural history; Roman, Romanesque, Gothic,
This is an astonish complete, well preserved and kept medieval cities in the world, with TOLEDO, ALBARRACIN & URBINO. Sugested to use a complete day for the visit.

This was truly wonderful. We were there just before christmas so there were few tourists. Around the 14th century cathedral was the highlight for me. The magnificent stained glass inside was awe inspiring.
Our first visit to France and Carcassonne. Amazing historic old cite. Lots of places to eat and shopping. Did the headphones tour about the history of the cite. Very interesting...amazing.

Highly recommended. If you can, get a tour guide to explain the history to get so much more out or the experience. Don't forget to also visit the Old Bastide (New town) on the other side of the river - fantastic shops, restaurants, cafes, market stalls, etc, etc.

The castel has been restored and as you go on the tour the story of the restoration is explained and can be in most languages thanks to some handheld devices. There are quite a few stairs some steep so not fo the feint hearted. You can also walk the ramparts which you really do

Fabulous medieval city. Spend an entire day and enjoy walking all around viewing exhibits, art work and learning about the history and how peopled lived. Definitely take a walking tour, very well done and interesting.

This place is small but very beautiful and full of history. It’s not easy to find a free table for a lunch and the service in shops and restaurants is pretty bad. The place is great to see but not for coming back.

Anyone who enjoys history or architecture should visit the city. A walk back in time. Massive preservation undertaking that is awe-inspiring.

amazing castle, a must see when in carcassonne, had food which was good. views were great, lovely at night

This medieval city was the highlight of our entire trip! it was so amazing to walk within the history. the shops and food were excellent and not expensive! We stayed 2 days and nights with the castle walls.The entire family, teens to senior enjoyed themselves.

I was in the area for a work trip so popped by, I was blown away at the scale of it, very impressive and lots of history, some lovely bars, shops and restaurants in side the walls too. We worth a visit.

Fantastic to visit at Christmas and see all the locals dressed in medieval attire. Clothes shops are a bit pricey, they don't really aim for bargain hunters anyway - quite top end goods. Well worth a visit to soak up the atmoshpere.

Very beautiful and probably a must see, but very touristic as well. It feels a little bit as if you are walking around in a Disney set.

It is by far one of the most amazing experiences, it is full of little stores inside, nice people great food....all in this medieval piece of art
Pay for a tour, you get so much information, very interesting. We got there early and had no problems with parking near the city.

I say "hidden" because on a tour from Portugal to Spain to France and then back to Spain, the French town of Carcassonne was just a convenient half-way lunch stop near the Spanish/Catalan border. Two hours was enough to be enchanted; pity that the stay couldn't have been longer.

Nice to visit this castle and city within the castle walls. There is no cost to looking around the castle and there's a lot to see without having to pay to access a small part within the walls. Some lovely small shops and restaurants in this area. Not much else to do In
It is like a medieval 5th Avenue, little shops everywhere, restaurants, there are horses and it has an interesting construction.

We visited Carcassonne on a private excursion from a cruise with Yves at Buscapades and it was great. The city is beautiful and easy to tour on your own. The castle was interesting and the cathedral was breathtaking. Loved it!!
This is the primary reason for a visit to Carcassonne, and it definitely is worth the time to enjoy.
really impressive old walled city of enormous history, really good selection of restaurants, and the abundant souvenier shops.. great for history buffs.. stunning views.. and lit up at night..

We made a stop in Carcassonne on our way to the Luberon area and we were pleased that we did. It's a great little village, full of shops, restaurants and other goodies. It was fun to explore and walk around the 'castle' wall. You don't need a full day here, we stopped a

Absolutely loved this placed as I am interested in the history and the Cathars. Very historic. Very tough on the feet due to the cobbled streets!

I was overwhelmed by the beauty and history. I travelled alone to this amazing place and still wondered around for several hours just soaking up the rich history and sheer beauty.
Well worth a visit. We found plenty to see and do in the Cite and town across the river. Food and drink a little on the expensive side, but it is a major tourist attraction!

This is a gem of a spot. If you have children, they will be able to run amok on the extensive grounds. Fabulous narration and in believable views from the citadel. A bit over touristy in the town but it is easy to get past that. Pack a jacket for the wind!
What a great place to visit spent two days exploring this castle taking our time to take it all in There are some lovely restaurants to take a break or the odd glass of wine
Interesting defensive building. Pity that visits to the castle close very early, as well as almost all shops around.

This was a highlight of our 5 week tour of South France Put this medieval city on your bucket list and if you do the museum tour do the audio guide

One of the more interesting castles to visit simply because it is so old. An ancient site that continued to be of historic importance due to a strategic location at the one time border between France and Spain. Shops and restaurants abound - slightly touristy but still cool.

We only spent one night here .. so made the most of our visit .. the whole citadel is a marvel of old building skills .. so well cared for and lovely to stroll around and explore .. a stunning destination and would recommend

Beautiful double walled Gallo-Roman city with a well restored Château. We toured the chateau and walked the town wall-self guided tour, and ate at a wonderful restaurant within the town walls. Parking is available outside the gates (Porte Narbonnaise). Very busy in the summer

A great castle full of life inside: restaurants and shops in every corner. The cathedral is inside and a great building with wonderful glass windows. We visited it all and it's full of wonderful views. Impressive!

Just fantastic and awe inspiring. wander the narrow cobbled streets, soak up the atmosphere, be amazed by the middle aged ramparts. A truely must see place.

This is worth at least a full day to browse the shops and enjoy the restaurants. The cathedral is magnificent. Definitely worth going to the museum. Rich in history.

First time to carcasonne and was not disappointed. Well worth a visit. I really recommend that you pay to go into the chateau and ramparts. But pay for your ticket at the tourist office. Saves the queues

A lovely city, full of cobbled streets, it has a great feel for the place. i had been wanting to visit for years and certainly wasn't dissapointed. loved it

It's hard not seeing yourself as a knight or a lady when you're walking around in this city. Absolutely stunning!

Wonderful experience, walked the castle at night and then visited during the day, worth paying for the tour and walking the castle walls, a great piece of history!

Easy walking medieval city a must see for any visitor to the region. Plenty of shops and restaurants and wonderful photogenic sights

Great shops and restaurants as well as getting to walk around and through the medieval city. Catch the little train into the city centre for a nice day then return for just a few Euros. Great views of the city and surrounding mountains, just wonderful

A wonderfully preserved walk through history itself. A highlight! Plenty of restaurants, cafes, shops and delights to satisfy you. With an incredible view of the city!

After the crowds of the day leave! Wandering the windy streets takes you to another time. Views from the ramparts are wonderful.

text.wiki:
Stade Toulousain (French pronunciation: ​[stad tuluzɛ̃]) (Occitan: Estadi Tolosenc), also referred to as Toulouse, is a French rugby union club from Toulouse in Occitania and the reigning Top 14 champion. Toulouse is one of the most successful clubs in Europe, having won the Heineken Cup a joint record four times – in 1996, 2003, 2005 and 2010. They were also runners-up in 2004 and 2008 against London Wasps and Munster, respectively. Stade Toulousain have also won a record 20 French Championship titles. It is traditionally one of the main providers for the French national team.  Their home ground is the Stade Ernest-Wallon. However, big Top 14 matches along with Heineken Cup games are often played at the Stadium Municipal de Toulouse. The club colours are red, black and white.


== History ==


=== Foundation ===
Before 1907 rugby in Toulouse was only played in schools or universities. In 1893, students of secondary school "Lycée de Toulouse" got together in "les Sans Soucis". Once attending university the same students founded "l'Olympique Toulousain", which became "Stade Olympien des Etudiants de Toulouse" (SOET) a few years later in 1896. In the same period, 'non-students' grouped in "le Sport Atléthique Toulousain" (SAT) while students of the veterinary school created "l'Union Sportive de l'Ecole Vétérinaire" (USEV). Both entities merged in 1905 and called themselves "Véto-Sport". Finally in 1907, Stade Toulousain was founded resulting from a union between the SOET and Véto-Sport.


=== Early years ===

Stade Toulousain played its first final of the national title French Championship in 1909 and lost it to Stade Bordelais Université Club (17–0) in Toulouse. In 1912 Stade Toulousain won its first national title. It had to wait until 1922 before it won its second. However the 1920s were a golden era for the club. Their first final action in the 1920s was in 1921, when they were defeated by USA Perpignan. Despite losing in 1921, the side went on to win the 1922, 1923, 1924, 1926 and 1927 championships.


=== 1930s to 1950s ===
The following decades were relatively quiet after such a dominant era during the 1920s. Stade Toulousain would not make it to any grand finals during the 1930s, and it would not be until the late 1940s when they would return. However they did contest the Challenge Yves du Manoir with RC Toulon in 1934, though it ended in a nil-all tie and both teams were winners. The club made it to the final of the 1947 championship, and claimed the premiership, beating SU Agen, 10 to 3. However, no such championships followed, the club was again relatively quiet on the championship. It was 22 years in the waiting; Toulouse made it to the final, but were defeated by the CA Bègles club.


=== 1970s to 1980s ===
In 1971 Toulouse contested the Challenge Yves du Manoir against US Dax, losing 18 to 8. Eleven years after the CA Bègles defeat, the club was again disappointed in the final, being defeated by AS Béziers in the championship game of 1980. The latter end of the decade was however, reminiscent of the 1920s sides. Toulouse were again contesting the Challenge Yves du Manoir for the 1984 season, though they lost to RC Narbonne 17 to 3. They did however claim their first championship since 1947, defeating RC Toulon in the 1985 final. The following season saw them successfully defend their championship, defeating SU Agen in the final. After a number of defeats in the Challenge Yves du Manoir finals, Toulouse defeated US Dax to win the 1988 competition. Both Toulon and Agen won the following premierships (1987 and 1988) but Toulouse won another championship in 1989.


=== 1990s to present ===

The dominance continued in the 1990s, starting with a grand final loss in 1991, and a Challenge Yves du Manoir championship in 1993, defeating Castres 13 to 8 in the final. The mid-1990s saw Stade Toulousain become a major force yet again, as the club claimed four premierships in a row, winning the championship in 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997, as well as the Challenge Yves du Manoir in 1995. The club emulated its success in the European Rugby Cup, becoming the first ever champions in the 1995–96 season.
The late 1990s and the 2000s saw the club again reach great heights. The club won the Challenge Yves du Manoir in 1998, defeating Stade Français Paris, and the 1999 championship as well as the 2001 championship and were runners-up in the 2003 season, losing to Stade Français in the final. As the club had done in the mid-1990s, Stade Toulousain replicated this success in the European Rugby Cup, winning the 2002–03 championship and the 2004–05 championship. The club made it to the final of the 2005–06 Top 14, and despite only trailing Biarritz 9–6 at half time, Toulouse could not prevent a second-half whitewash, eventually going down 40–13. They ended their seven-year title drought with a 26–20 win over ASM Clermont Auvergne on 28 June 2008.  In 2008 they narrowly lost a Heineken Cup Final to Munster by 3 points. In 2010 Toulouse defeated Leinster to reach the final where they faced Biarritz Olympique at Stade de France in Paris on Saturday 22 May 2010. Toulouse won the game by 21–19 to claim their fourth Heineken Cup title, making them the only club to ever win the title four times. Stade Toulousain is also the only French club to have taken part in all the editions of Heineken Cup since its creation (17, with the 2011–12 season).  They won the French championship in 2011 against Montpellier (15–10) and 2012 against Toulon (18–12). Stade Toulousain reached the semi-finals of the French championship 20 consecutive years (from 1994 to 2013).


== Stadium ==

Toulouse play their home games at the Stade Ernest-Wallon, which was built in the late 1980s and was recently renovated. Stade Toulousain is one of the three teams (all sports included) that own its stadium. It has a capacity of 19,500. The stadium however cannot always accommodate all the fans of the Toulouse club. For the larger fixtures, such as championship or Heineken Cup games or play-offs, the fixture may be moved to Stadium Municipal, which has double capacity, 38,000. The stadium was used for numerous matches at the 2007 Rugby World Cup


== Honours ==


=== Rugby Union ===
World Club Championship:
Champions: 1986, 1990
Heineken Cup:
Champions: 1996, 2003, 2005, 2010
Runners-up: 2004, 2008
French Champions:
Champions: 1912, 1922, 1923, 1924, 1926, 1927, 1947, 1985, 1986, 1989, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1999, 2001, 2008, 2011, 2012, 2019
Runners-up: 1903, 1909, 1921, 1969, 1980, 1991, 2003, 2006
Challenge Yves du Manoir:
Champions: 1934, 1988, 1993, 1995, 1998
Runners-up: 1971 1984
French Cup:
Champions: 1946, 1947, 1984
Runners-up: 1949, 1985


=== Football ===
Champions of Midi:
Champions: 1905, 1906, 1907, 1908, 1909, 1910, 1911, 1912, 1913, 1914


== European record ==
Toulouse qualified for the Heineken Cup in every season of that competition's existence (1995–96 to 2013–14), and played in the inaugural season of the replacement competition, the European Rugby Champions Cup. The club had the best competition record in the Heineken Cup, having won the competition four times.


== Current standings ==


== Current squad ==

text.wiki:
Henri Marie Raymond de Toulouse-Lautrec-Monfa (24 November 1864 – 9 September 1901), commonly known as just Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (UK:  ON-ree də too-LOOZ loh-TREK, US:  on-REE -⁠, French: [ɑ̃ʁi də tuluz lotʁɛk]), was a French painter, printmaker, draughtsman, caricaturist, and illustrator whose immersion in the colorful and theatrical life of Paris in the late 19th century allowed him to produce a collection of enticing, elegant, and provocative images of the modern, sometimes decadent, affairs of those times.
Toulouse-Lautrec is among the best-known painters of the Post-Impressionist period, with Paul Cézanne, Vincent van Gogh, and Paul Gauguin.
In a 2005 auction at Christie's auction house, La Blanchisseuse, his early painting of a young laundress, sold for US$22.4 million and set a new record for the artist for a price at auction.


== Early life ==
Henri Marie Raymond de Toulouse-Lautrec-Monfa was born at the Hôtel du Bosc in Albi, Tarn, in the Midi-Pyrénées region of France, the firstborn child of Alphonse Charles Comte de Toulouse-Lautrec-Monfa (1838–1913) and his wife Adèle Zoë Tapié de Celeyran (1841–1930). The last part of his name means he was a member of an aristocratic family (descendants of the Counts of Toulouse and Odet de Foix, Vicomte de Lautrec and the Viscounts of Montfa, a village and commune of the Tarn department of southern France, close to the cities of Castres and Toulouse). His younger brother was born in 1867 but died the following year. Both sons enjoyed the titres de courtoisie of Comte. If Henri had outlived his father, he would have been accorded the family title of Comte de Toulouse-Lautrec.After the death of his brother, Toulouse-Lautrec's parents separated and a nanny eventually took care of him. At the age of eight, Toulouse-Lautrec went to live with his mother in Paris, where he drew sketches and caricatures in his exercise workbooks. The family quickly realized that his talents lay in drawing and painting. A friend of his father, René Princeteau, sometimes visited to give informal lessons. Some of Toulouse-Lautrec's early paintings are of horses, a specialty of Princeteau, and a subject Lautrec revisited in his "Circus Paintings".In 1875, Toulouse-Lautrec returned to Albi because his mother had concerns about his health. He took thermal baths at Amélie-les-Bains, and his mother consulted doctors in the hope of finding a way to improve her son's growth and development.


== Disability and health problems ==

Toulouse-Lautrec's parents, the Comte and Comtesse, were first cousins (his grandmothers were sisters), and his congenital health conditions were attributed to a family history of inbreeding.At the age of 13, Toulouse-Lautrec fractured his right femur, and at 14, he fractured his left femur. The breaks did not heal properly. Modern physicians attribute this to an unknown genetic disorder, possibly pycnodysostosis (sometimes known as Toulouse-Lautrec Syndrome), or a variant disorder along the lines of osteopetrosis, achondroplasia, or osteogenesis imperfecta. Rickets aggravated by praecox virilism has also been suggested. Afterward, his legs ceased to grow, so that as an adult he was extremely short (1.42 m or 4 ft 8 in). He developed an adult-sized torso while retaining his child-sized legs. Additionally, he is reported to have had hypertrophied genitals.Physically unable to participate in many activities enjoyed by boys his age, Toulouse-Lautrec immersed himself in art. He became a prominent Post-Impressionist painter, art nouveau illustrator, and lithographer, and, through his works, recorded many details of the late-19th-century bohemian lifestyle in Paris. Toulouse-Lautrec contributed several illustrations to the magazine Le Rire during the mid-1890s.After initially failing college entrance exams, he passed his second attempt and completed his studies.


== Paris ==

During a stay in Nice, France, his progress in painting and drawing impressed Princeteau, who persuaded Toulouse-Lautrec's parents to let him return to Paris and study under the portrait painter Léon Bonnat. He moved to Paris in 1882. Toulouse-Lautrec's mother had high ambitions and, with the aim of her son becoming a fashionable and respected painter, used their family's influence to get him into Bonnat's studio. He was drawn to Montmartre, the area of Paris famous for its bohemian lifestyle and the haunt of artists, writers, and philosophers. Studying with Bonnat placed Toulouse-Lautrec in the heart of Montmartre, an area he rarely left over the next 20 years.
After Bonnat took a new job, Toulouse-Lautrec moved to the studio of Fernand Cormon in 1882 and studied for a further five years and established the group of friends he kept for the rest of his life. At this time, he met Émile Bernard and Vincent van Gogh. Cormon, whose instruction was more relaxed than Bonnat's, allowed his pupils to roam Paris, looking for subjects to paint. During this period, Toulouse-Lautrec had his first encounter with a prostitute (reputedly sponsored by his friends), which led him to paint his first painting of a prostitute in Montmartre, a woman rumored to be Marie-Charlet.


=== Early career ===
In 1885, Lautrec started to exhibit his work at the cabaret of Aristide Bruant's Mirliton.With his studies finished, in 1887, he participated in an exposition in Toulouse using the pseudonym "Tréclau," the verlan of the family name "Lautrec." He later exhibited in Paris with Van Gogh and Louis Anquetin.In 1885, Toulouse Lautrec met Suzanne Valadon. He made several portraits of her and supported her ambition as an artist. It is believed that they were lovers and that she wanted to marry him. Their relationship ended, and Valadon attempted suicide in 1888.


=== Rise to recognition ===
In 1888, the Belgian critic Octave Maus invited him to present eleven pieces at the Vingt (the Twenties) exhibition in Brussels in February. Van Gogh's brother Theo bought Poudre de Riz (Rice Powder) for 150 francs for the Goupil & Cie gallery.
From 1889 until 1894, Toulouse-Lautrec took part in the Salon des Indépendants regularly. He made several landscapes of Montmartre. Tucked deep into Montmartre in the garden of Monsieur Pere Foret, Toulouse-Lautrec executed a series of pleasant en plein air paintings of Carmen Gaudin, the same red-headed model who appears in The Laundress (1888).
In 1890 during the banquet of the XX exhibition in Brussels, he challenged to a duel the artist Henri de Groux who criticized van Gogh works. Groux apologized, and the duel never took place.


=== The Ladies ===
In addition to his growing alcoholism, Toulouse-Lautrec also frequented prostitutes. He was fascinated by their lifestyle and the lifestyle of the "urban underclass" and incorporated those characters into his paintings. Fellow painter Édouard Vuillard later said that while Toulouse-Lautrec did engage in sex with prostitutes, "the real reasons for his behavior were moral ones ... Lautrec was too proud to submit to his lot, as a physical freak, an aristocrat cut off from his kind by his grotesque appearance. He found an affinity between his condition and the moral penury of the prostitute."The girls in the brothels inspired Toulouse-Lautrec. He would frequently visit one located in Rue d'Amboise, where he had a favorite called Mireille. He created about a hundred drawings and fifty paintings inspired by the life of these women. In 1892 and 1893, he created a series of two women kissing called Le Lit, and in 1894 painted Salón de la Rue des Moulins from memory in his studio.He declared, "A model is always a stuffed doll, but these women are alive. I wouldn't venture to pay them the hundred sous to sit for me, and god knows whether they would be worth it. They stretch out on the sofas like animals, make no demand and they are not in the least bit conceited."
He was well appreciated by the ladies, saying, "I have found girls of my own size! Nowhere else do I feel so much at home".


=== The Moulin Rouge ===
When the Moulin Rouge cabaret opened in 1889, Toulouse-Lautrec was commissioned to produce a series of posters. His mother had left Paris and, though he had a regular income from his family, making posters offered him a living of his own. Other artists looked down on the work, but he ignored them. The cabaret reserved a seat for him and displayed his paintings. Among the well-known works that he painted for the Moulin Rouge and other Parisian nightclubs are depictions of the singer Yvette Guilbert; the dancer Louise Weber, better known as La Goulue (The Glutton) who created the French can-can; and the much subtler dancer Jane Avril.


== London ==

Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec's family were Anglophiles, and though he was not as fluent as he pretended to be, he spoke English well enough. He traveled to London, where he was commissioned by the J. & E. Bella company to make a poster advertising their paper confetti (plaster confetti was banned after the 1892 Mardi Gras) and the bicycle advert La Chaîne Simpson.While in London, he met and befriended Oscar Wilde. When Wilde faced imprisonment in Britain, Toulouse-Lautrec became a very vocal supporter of him, and his portrait of Oscar Wilde was painted the same year as Wilde's trial.


== Alcoholism ==

Toulouse-Lautrec was mocked for his short stature and physical appearance, which led him to abuse alcohol.He initially drank only beer and wine, but his tastes expanded into liquor, namely absinthe. The Earthquake cocktail (Tremblement de Terre) is attributed to Toulouse-Lautrec: a potent mixture containing half absinthe and half cognac in a wine goblet. Due to his underdeveloped legs, he walked with the aid of a cane, which he hollowed out and kept filled with liquor in order to ensure that he was never without alcohol.


== Cooking skills ==
A fine and hospitable cook, Toulouse-Lautrec built up a collection of favorite recipes – some original, some adapted – which were posthumously published by his friend and dealer Maurice Joyant as L'Art de la Cuisine. The book was republished in English translation in 1966 as The Art of Cuisine – a tribute to his inventive (and wide-ranging) cooking.


== Death ==

By February 1899, Toulouse-Lautrec's alcoholism began to take its toll and he collapsed from exhaustion and the effects of alcoholism. His family had him committed to Folie Saint-James, a sanatorium in Neuilly-sur-Seine for three months. While he was committed, he drew 39 circus portraits. After his release, he returned to the Paris studio for a time and then traveled throughout France. His physical and mental health began to decline rapidly owing to alcoholism and syphilis, which he reportedly contracted from Rosa La Rouge, a prostitute who was the subject of several of his paintings.On 9 September 1901, at the age of 36, he died from complications due to alcoholism and syphilis at his mother's estate, Château Malromé, in Saint-André-du-Bois. He is buried in Cimetière de Verdelais, Gironde, a few kilometers from the estate. His last words reportedly were "Le vieux con!" ("the old fool"), his goodbye to his father, though another version has been suggested, in which he used the word "hallali," a term used by huntsmen at the moment the hounds kill their prey: "Je savais, Papa, que vous ne manqueriez pas l'hallali" ("I knew, papa, that you wouldn't miss the death.").After Toulouse-Lautrec's death, his mother, Adèle Comtesse de Toulouse-Lautrec-Monfa, and his art dealer, Maurice Joyant, continued promoting his artwork. His mother contributed funds for a museum to be created in Albi, his birthplace, to show his works. This Musée Toulouse-Lautrec owns the most extensive of his works.


== Art ==

In his less-than-20-year career, Toulouse-Lautrec created:

737 canvased paintings
275 watercolors
363 prints and posters
5,084 drawings
some ceramic and stained-glass work
an unknown number of lost worksHis debt to the Impressionists, particularly the more figurative painters like Manet and Degas, is apparent, that within his works, one can draw parallels to the detached barmaid at A Bar at the Folies-Bergère by Manet and the behind-the-scenes ballet dancers of Degas. His style was also influenced by the classical Japanese woodprints, which became popular in art circles in Paris.He excelled at depicting people in their working environments, with the color and movement of the gaudy nightlife present but the glamour stripped away. He was a master at painting crowd scenes where each figure was highly individualized. At the time they were painted, the individual figures in his larger paintings could be identified by silhouette alone, and the names of many of these characters have been recorded. His treatment of his subject matter, whether as portraits, in scenes of Parisian nightlife, or as intimate studies, has been described as alternately "sympathetic" and "dispassionate".Toulouse-Lautrec's skilled depiction of people relied on his painterly style, which is highly linear and emphasizes contour. He often applied paint in long, thin brushstrokes, which would leave much of the board underneath showing through the paint. Many of his works may be best described as "drawings in coloured paint."On 20 August 2018, Toulouse-Lautrec was the featured artist on the BBC television program Fake or Fortune?. Researchers attempted to discover whether he created two discovered sketchbooks.


== In popular culture ==


=== Films ===
Moulin Rouge (1952), portrayed by José Ferrer
Casino Royale (1967): Tremble dresses as Toulouse-Lautrec for Vesper
The Aristocats (1970): As an animated painting kitten, voiced by Gary Dubin
Revenge of the Pink Panther (1978), Clouseau, disguised as Toulouse-Lautrec, played by Peter Sellers
Lautrec (1998), directed by Roger Planchon
Moulin Rouge! (2001), portrayed by John Leguizamo
Midnight in Paris (2011), portrayed by Vincent Menjou Cortes


=== Television ===
In SpongeBob SquarePants, in episode 11b of season 1. During a scene in which Patrick and SpongeBob are carrying Squidward around in servitude to him, with Squidward complaining it is "too hot" or "too wet," they stumble onto an aquatic version of the painting La Troupe de Mlle. Églantine. Squidward quips that it is "too loose, Lautrec."
In Sesame Street, La Troupe de Mlle. Églantine was also used as an animation about the letter D for "dance".


=== Literature ===
Sacré Bleu: A Comedy d'Art, by Christopher Moore, in which the bon vivant artist plays the role of co-detective with the fictional lead, Lucien Lessard, in trying to unravel the death of mutual friend Vincent van Gogh.
Sayonara Sorcier, by Hozumi, a Japanese manga series where Toulouse-Lautrec appears as a main character aside Theodorus Van Gogh and Paul Gauguin.
Lust for Life (1934), historical novel based on the life of Vincent van Gogh.
Moulin Rouge (novel), by Pierre La Mure (1950), historical novel based on the life of Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec.

At least, this is our second visit here and it is a gallery I could enjoy visiting every few years. The obvious reason to visit a gallery is to enjoy the artworks and of course Lautrec is in the Premier League but in addition it's just a beautiful place to explore - recommended

I've always enjoyed Lautrec's art, so it was a real pleasure to see so much of it, from his early works to his late ones, in a variety of mediums. Because of a temporary problem walking, I was afraid I would have to forgo this visit, but the museum has a wheelchair available for
Probably the most extensive collection of Toulouse Lautrec's work in the world. The large exhibition is housed in the old bishop's palace which is well worth a visit in its own right.

A very nice collection of Toulouse-Lautrec paintings and lithographs. The lighting could be better in some parts of the exhibition (lights were very dim) and they could offer more languages for the descriptions since everything is mostly in French. The gift store is very weak,
Lovely museum carrying a substantial amount of Toulouse-Latrec works. Several floors will keep one entertained for hours.
I had never seen Toulouse-Lautrec early works, interesting works, an in depth look at the master's work. Do not miss going upstairs

Spent a too-short time here but it was part of a tour and we had a time schedule. The museum is definitely worth a leisurely visit so one can really read the information provided, take in the work, and visit the gardens. The building itself is wonderful and worth taking note of.
Located in the old bishops palace built like a fortress. The day I went was a cultural celebration day and museum entry was free. Plenty of works by Toulouse-Latrec. An excellent visit!
If you go, you'll see artwork from throughout Toulouse's life along with a very well done narrative of his life, his art, and his interests.

From the gorgeous gardens surrounding the museums with the lovely views along the river, to the classic art on show. This place scores on all fronts, don’t miss the tourist information centre by the front entrance if you are unsure of anything.
From the beginning to ADV poster, it's well explained (audioguide available in French, English and Spanish). It takes 90' at least
There are a lot of pictures in the museum, not all of equal quality, but a very good history of his paintings since his teenage years until his untimely death.

A must-see on visiting Albi, and good value. Plenty of works from all stages of the artist's career. These were well displayed, and helpfully complemented by information sheets in several languages. We spent the best part of two hours looking round the museum, and also enjoyed
An extensive collection of Lautrec's work well laid out. Information sheets in most rooms and in English which makes a change for France. Spent 2 1/2 happy hours here. A must for Lautrec lovers.
Interesting man, Toulouse Lautrec and beautiful exhibit of his works. We used the self-guided tour which was easy. A guided tour would have been ideal but we had not thought ahead to do that.

This interesting museum displays almost exclusively the works of Toulouse Lautrec. His studies of the working lives of prostitutes in brothels show an empathy that is realistic and totally removed from any salacious temptations, even though he was apparently a frequent customer.

Great to see actual Toulouse Lautrec paintings up close. Would have liked to see a few more from his Folies Begere era, but well worth visiting. I was very surprised that photography (flash off) was allowed.

I love the art work by Toulouse-Lautrec so this museum was high on my 'To Do! ' List whilst in Albi. A great collection of the artist's oils, drawings and posters. Some iconic works and some I have never seen before.

While not a big fan of Toulouse-Lautrec myself I still enjoyed learning more about the life and the work of this popular Fin de Siècle painter. You'll find that you know many of his paintings and posters. No Montmartre shop is without a T-L collection of trays, mouse pads, bags

A fabulous building and well displayed pictures. Excellent laminated cards in each room describing the art. There is also the option of hiring a recorded narrative. Doesn't close for lunch during July & Augus.

A comprehensive collection of the works of Toulouse-Lautrec, child of Albi. The vibrancy, brilliance and creativity of each work was mesmerising. His portrayal of people from the spectrum of humanity is both sensitive and respectful. It is a must-see on your visit to Albi.

Monsieur Lautrec was a talented painter of posters but looking at the rest of his art it was not great shakes. Compare him to Renoir (or perhaps that is not fair) then he certainly falls short. sorry no pun intended but it does go to show why cousins should not marry! Anyway

World's largest collection of artworks by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec in a 13th-century palace. The Musée Toulouse-Lautrec is an art museum in Albi, southern France, dedicated mainly to the work of the painter Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec who was born near Albi.
We visited Albi primarily to see the art museum. We were not disappointed. There were some great exhibits.
Very good collection of Toulouse Lautrec. Especially the affiches are ok. Located in a old nice castle.
€9 per adult entrance and it's wonderful. A must see. Situated in an amazing building and with some wonderful paintings by Lautrec and his contemporaries.

Beautifully restored, sensitively inserted modern exhibition spaces with a vast collections of Lautrec artwork over 3 stories, but the main event is that amazing view over the gardens an river from the terraces!
Fascinating to see the early and other work of Toulouse Lautrec, so well known for the later posters for Parisian clubs but with much more to show.

Tremendous exhibition of all his periods and great history facts about the man. You will need at least 1.5 hours to go round exhibition. Information cards in each area which give you an insight into some of the paintings on display.

Great to see so many originals from the sketches to the finished paintings. Well laid out in a purebred building which in itself is very interesting. Great information in each gallery in a variety of languages to explain the works. Towards the end though I was running out of

You may be familiar with Toulouse Lautrec's posters of the Moulin Rouge but this gallery shows what a talented all-round artist he was. In his short life he achieved a great deal and the gallery presents the full range of his outputs. The exhibition is cleverly curated and the
If you like Toulouse Lautrec then this is a must. The art work is beautifully set out and the information is very good.

Old Albi is a gorgeous town, beautiful any time of the year. The Musee Toulouse-Lautrec is a must for anyone interested in TL's art and life, as well as Impressionism and Post-Impressionism in general. The collection was better than I expected, and larger than I expected. It
A well organised museum with helpful staff. There seem to be many levels with lifts available for people unable to use stairs. To absorb it fully will take a couple of hours.

The museum is located in the former bishops palace, so the building is also a treasure. The artwork is nicely displayed, and there are large laminated pages in most rooms with extra information in French, Spanish and English.

It's a delicious museum in a wonderful cornice, famous masterpieces of Toulouse-Lautrec from early life to maturity. I don't understand why is banned photograph while everywhere in all France is possible except temporary exhibit.

Glad we have been as were in Albi and trying to visit all places of interest. Interesting building with good views over the river. The history of the building in relation to the Cathars is interesting
From his early work through to his final days, a fine collection of his work including some of the more famous posters.
Well worth a visit to view an extensive collection of all aspects of His art, from early days to a final portrait shortly before his death.

The museum in a former bishop's palace. Very interesting, lot's of information. Next to the cathedral.
I'm not a fan of Lautrec but after going through the museum, I understand the artist and his life and work better.

Toulouse-Lautrec is probably known for his long name, but I hadn't heard so much about his works. It was very interesting to see how his style changed throughout the years. Worth a visit!

Fabulous art collection in the heart of Albi, where Lautrec himself used to live. Nice relaxed atmosphere and lots of good information cards to give more background if you're interested. Beware of the closing time in the middle of the day (between 12 and 2pm).

Who doesn't know Toulouse-Lautrec for his vivid posters and his intense works reflecting sometimes the seedier side of life in Paris. His early life was spent around the Albi area and in this museum you can see how his talent was already very apparent at the age of 15 or 16

Musee Toulouse-Lautrec is a treasure both in its building and gardens, as well as its,exhibition. Allow at least three hours to see the museum and its contents.
This is a gem of a museum, with a magnificent garden with beautiful views on the river Tarn. Toulouse Lautrec is of course well represented but so are a lot of other famous painters.

We did a day trip from Toulouse to Albi, and visited both the cathedral and museum. Both are highly recommended. There is much to see and do.

The world's largest collection of the artist's work....an amazing exhibit and the best part is that there is a very detailed audio guide available in English. If only other French museums could provide audio guides in other languages than French for their many tourists.
The museum has a vast exhibition of Toulouse-Lautrec's works and the history of the artist, both in English and a few other languages which made for a pleasant visit

I was looking forward to seeing this museum for years. As many photos & posters that you have seen of Lautrec nothing can be as wonderful as seeing the originals. A warm welcome and a breathtaking show.

Lovely medieval episcopal residence. The Toulouse Lautrec collection is extensive and amazing but the building it is housed in is also incredible. Right next to the Cathedral so not to be missed. Closes at noon.

We hummed and hawed about paying the 9 Eurostar to get in but am glad we went. The museum gave a good history to the development of Tolouse lautrec's art. Well laid out and small amounts of information available. An audio set was another 4 euros.

An outstanding museum in a lovely historic building. The exhibits well planned and give you overview of the painter's life and how his work changed over time. This might the one of the cheapest museum in EU. Very well done! I hope I get to see this museum again.
Outstanding display of Toulouse-Lautrec art. Modestly priced, easily accessible, audio guides available, but they not necessary because each room had excellent written descriptions.

Wow. Is all I can say. The collection is huge, well displayed and informative. It shows the ages and techniques Henri Toulouse-Lautrec went through before he came famous with his classic Moulin Rouge poster type art. For €9 it's a bargain and the views as you walk around are

be prepared to spend a good few hours as there are lots of exhibits to see. Very informative with information in several languages. Both the building and the exhibits were well worth seeing.
Apart from the atmospheric building there were lots of art works to see. Quiet and spacious. I would highly recommend it.
Besides loving his work, you can admire the inside of the palace where the museum is located. Totally worth a visit!

This museum looks small from the outside, but actually rambles on and on in the bishops' palace. The collection of the work of Toulouse is extensive and includes drawings, posters and paintings. A must see!
An amazing collection of Lautrec's work. Wall to wall enjoyment. It was surprising to see the range of his talent. The museum building itself is fantastic.

What with all the sketches and draft- drawings there a a large number of rooms to see. It therefore pays one (in tme saved) to be selective over which works to dawdle in front of. The curator's prepared information on some of the works are (likewise) somewhat sketchy.

We travelled specially to Albi to visit this and were not disappointed at all. Nice museum and collection, beautiful building and gardens.
